subject: Ensures User is member of tenant in ec2 validation
messages: [{'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2012-11-22 14:18:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nwrong change id'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-22 14:10:35.000000000', 'message': 'Ensures User is member of tenant in ec2 validation

It is possible that a user is no longer a member of a tenant when
they attempt to use an ec2 token. This checks to make sure that
the user still has at least one valid role in the tenant before
authenticating them. This should automatically work for the s3
version as well since it is a subclass.

Fixes bug 1064914

Change-Id: Ie10be6f10693c22c4dfeb737667d96b2f17d26c3
'}]
commit_message:
Ensures User is member of tenant in ec2 validation

It is possible that a user is no longer a member of a tenant when
they attempt to use an ec2 token. This checks to make sure that
the user still has at least one valid role in the tenant before
authenticating them. This should automatically work for the s3
version as well since it is a subclass.

Fixes bug 1064914

Change-Id: Ie10be6f10693c22c4dfeb737667d96b2f17d26c3

Is there a packaging mailing list that should be notified of this change?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-20 19:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

is this something that needs broader agreement by other projects? I don't know where we stand on shared dependencies."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-11-20 20:48:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There isn't a packaging mailing list. I think in general we just send something to openstack@ and assume packagers notice."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-20 21:15:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems fine to me.  

(With my Fedora packaging hat on) I added pbrady in case he could come up with a reason this would be a problem for Fedora packaging.  We already include newer versions of both python-amqplib and python-kombu.  This patch doesn't change the minimum version, so I don't see any problems with it."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-21 02:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

cinder, quantum and oslo-incubator all  set kombu to 1.0.4 still.    perhaps oslo should start helping with some of the dependency versioning?'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-21 15:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Pity it wasn't noted which version of python-kombu caused the issue

precise has 1.4.3
fedora 17 and epel 6 have 1.1.3"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-22 09:04:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

General dependency management thoughts here - https://etherpad.openstack.org/process-dependency-management - but it's not up and running yet

I'm generally against pinning to a specific version. It doesn't reflect the reality distros face - they can't stop the package version moving forward in the distro just for the sake of a single user of that package

Rationale here sounds good - we know we work with newer kombu, we've no reason to think we don't work with 1.0.4, we suspect some versions in between don't work for us but we don't know specifically which ones

Appros of not much, there was some issue about older anyjson and newer kombu - see Icd2ed0ae56964e6ec91b32b81e0f5b65163e40e0"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-22 09:05:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-22 09:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Oslo's unit tests don't work with latest kombu btw - https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1082020"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-14 19:05:36.000000000', 'message': "Unpin amqplib and kombu requirements.

Ubuntu is using a much newer version of these libraries so we
shouldn't lock the versions in our infrasctructure. Using a > 1.0
of amqplib is particularly useful as it turns on keepalives by
default.

Change-Id: I956e70e0c39c76d1632fb708cd78aeb51adbd250
"}]
commit_message:
Unpin amqplib and kombu requirements.

Ubuntu is using a much newer version of these libraries so we
shouldn't lock the versions in our infrasctructure. Using a > 1.0
of amqplib is particularly useful as it turns on keepalives by
default.

Change-Id: I956e70e0c39c76d1632fb708cd78aeb51adbd250

commit_message:
Adapted to nova's compute_driver moving.

Nova moved the compute_driver into nova.virt.driver in recent changes.
It also provided 2 new functions load_compute_driver() and
compute_driver_matches().

Leveraging that change while still keeps folsom compatibility.

Change-Id: I53f6f295cef6173aaea26c9bbac977b3ae66c6d2

Enable the resource name to be retrieved from an object. Also allow a
ResourceIdentifier to be constructed from only the data passed through the
RPC API. This means we can use a single format for identifiers, but still
be able to extract important information such as the stack identifier and
resource name.

Change-Id: Ie9122cb1a835b30eb8e0713a9d5cdcb4a386eda7
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Improve the identifier class for Resources

Enable the resource name to be retrieved from an object. Also allow a
ResourceIdentifier to be constructed from only the data passed through the
RPC API. This means we can use a single format for identifiers, but still
be able to extract important information such as the stack identifier and
resource name.

Change-Id: Ie9122cb1a835b30eb8e0713a9d5cdcb4a386eda7
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

Created generic quantum.utils.parse_mappings function that detects
duplicate key or value strings, and changed openvswitch and
linuxbridge agents to use this to parse their mappings from physical

Also fixed some typos in comments.

commit_message:
Improve openvswitch and linuxbridge agents' parsing of mappings

Created generic quantum.utils.parse_mappings function that detects
duplicate key or value strings, and changed openvswitch and
linuxbridge agents to use this to parse their mappings from physical
networks to bridges or interfaces. Fixes bug 1067669.

Also fixed some typos in comments.

Change-Id: I342eaeeb6ff4c6e25d57d631f250faac082011b8

commit_message:
add port support when QuantumV2 subclass is used

fixes bug 1070045

Fix the current implementation by checking if FLAGS.network_api_class is a
subclass of nova.network.quantumv2.api.API.  Previously, the API would
not accept port references unless the network_api_class string was
anything other than the QuantumV2 class.  This limitation prevented
subclassing.

This changeset includes additional API unit tests focused on QuantumV2
and requested networks.

Change-Id: I6b7b7389e127ff8b084ac379cb9aebccc102620c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-21 21:08:42.000000000', 'message': "Xenapi: Don't resize down if not auto_disk_config

It is not safe to resize down an instance if the filesystem has not been
resized first, but with auto_disk_config == False there's no guarantee
that it has happened.  And not resizing down the disk space with the
instance allows for users to have more space on their instance than the
type should allow.

Fixes bug 1081225

Change-Id: I980c0699dfc272155e274a96d6e08e131c1372d9
"}]
commit_message:
Xenapi: Don't resize down if not auto_disk_config

It is not safe to resize down an instance if the filesystem has not been
resized first, but with auto_disk_config == False there's no guarantee
that it has happened.  And not resizing down the disk space with the
instance allows for users to have more space on their instance than the
type should allow.

Fixes bug 1081225

Change-Id: I980c0699dfc272155e274a96d6e08e131c1372d9

commit_message:
Remove obsolete config drive init.d example

Delete the example init.d script that uses the config drive. This
script is not compatible with the current implementation of
config drive.

Change-Id: I9cf5542ef84a206b9ac5dc05637b3f6ecaaba548

commit_message:
Add hosts extension to Cinder.

This adds the hosts extension to Cinder which is similar to
the extension by the same name in Nova.

This extension allows an admin user to check the status of
Cinder services on different hosts.  In addition it also
provides the capability to get host and project specific information
regarding volume count and space allocated for volumes on a specified
host.

Implements blueprint cinder-hosts-extension

Change-Id: Ic3679cfcd900baecdc2da17e42194cac99c9d422

commit_message:
Moving contrib to cinder.api

This moves over all contrib to a common place for all api versions to
use. Test directory structure has been adjusted to match.

For compatibility with old cinder config settings, we ignore the old
contrib path and use the new location.

progress on blueprint apiv2

Change-Id: If1a24fd3c4d15db559674a021f6928613966e3a1

commit_message:
Moving api v1 implementation into v1 directory

Adjusts paste to use composite factory for routing properly to v1 and
future api versions. Tests have been adjusted to match directory
structure.

progress on blueprint apiv2

Change-Id: I2cd3908705d224872b2d615cabe210fb1c453232

commit_message:
moving all middleware code in cinder.api.middleware

This includes auth, sizelimit, and faultwrapper middleware. Test
directory struture has been adjusted to match.

progress on blueprint apiv2

Change-Id: I62eecb208553abfee8dc8d2679264884b4cec153

commit_message:
Moving common api code into cinder.api

This is progress for beginning to have separate versions of the
cinder api. Common code that would be shared by v1, v2 etc will use
these modules, so we'll just move them to a common place. Test directory
structure has also been updated.

progress on blueprint apiv2

Change-Id: I99fd95fc3bb5d4f4fc3d9ef5b76b6372a1f6033d

This is likely failing because it requires the change from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16408..which is also blocked.'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-11-21 00:10:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16408 it this change -- I don't get your comment referencing the build problem.

Also I would expect to see the code that allows users to flip the 'bootable' bit included with this change."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-11-21 00:40:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Still WIP so no big deal.. but:

We do in fact only intend to cover the cases where the API was used to copy the image to the volume.  The dependency here is actually https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16172/

We're just using the glance info from the DB here."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2012-11-21 00:49:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for checking bswartz. Yeah, sorry wrong change referenced as jgriffith mentioned... Once that other change gets through, it should pass integration. 

In regards to your other concern: This blueprint only covers listing if a volume is bootable. With that in mind, in respect to conversations around the api implementation, it's not as simple as flipping a bit I'm afraid. The api assumes something is bootable if it contains volume_glance_metadata, which is the only way cinder knows for sure if something is bootable."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-11-21 02:41:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I found out that we already have support for reading glance images during volume creation, so an implementation that doesn't allow users to set the flag will actually not be too bad."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2012-11-21 18:38:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Ready For Review

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-14 09:30:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bug for sql identity authenticate.

Currently, sql backend of identity uses None as the default value of
tenant_ref in authenticate() method. But all other keytone codes treat
tenant as a dictionary, so this would trigger exception in some cases
(such as user-role-add). This patch fixes this problem by changing
tenant_ref default value to empty dictionary instead of None.

Change-Id: Ie639366b27ec8ada84abd339f40d15251d41f5f8
'}]
commit_message:
Fix bug for sql identity authenticate.

Currently, sql backend of identity uses None as the default value of
tenant_ref in authenticate() method. But all other keytone codes treat
tenant as a dictionary, so this would trigger exception in some cases
(such as user-role-add). This patch fixes this problem by changing
tenant_ref default value to empty dictionary instead of None.

Change-Id: Ie639366b27ec8ada84abd339f40d15251d41f5f8

commit_message:
Add --version as global parameter

This is a fix for bug 1068532, which is rather an improvement than a
bug.

A global parameter "--version" has been added which displays the
contents of a file called "versioninfo". It is just like the same as the
corresponding function within python-novaclient.

Maybe someone else thinks that's helpfull. It is only the local version
of the client, not the version of the API.

Change-Id: Ie365e4b664822affe7179cb9dc4763884d943667

I don't have a specific bug report for the unwanted behavior.  And I can't find an example in trunk right now.  But the current behavior is what led to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14867.  It also led to an issue with some unpublished code where a distinction is made between specifying an empty network and not passing one at all.

Even if it doesn't address any specific issue currently it allows a distinction to be made between creating an instance with a default network configuration versus an empty network configuration.  There are currently a few variations of checks in nova such as
if not requested_networks
if requested_networks is not None and len(requested_networks) != 0
possibly because nova code tends to default requested_networks to None but requests from novaclient end up setting that to [] in a lot of cases.  I would like to have a reasonable expectation that an unset requested_networks is None, and then [] could possibly mean something else."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-11-14 19:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

bah, didn't realize everything would get scrunched.  The tests were

[{'created': '2012-11-14 17:56:49.000000000', 'message': 'Distinguish between empty and no network.

python-novaclient was passing an empty network list to the api by
default.  This leads to unwanted behavior in other services that check
if network is None for some decisions.  Rather than change each of those
services python-novaclient no longer passes an empty network list by
default, but a user can still specify an emtpy network with
--empty-network

Change-Id: Ia00a16ec5bc5b51af9f2ba10f12b896edf57bfff
'}]
commit_message:
Distinguish between empty and no network.

python-novaclient was passing an empty network list to the api by
default.  This leads to unwanted behavior in other services that check
if network is None for some decisions.  Rather than change each of those
services python-novaclient no longer passes an empty network list by
default, but a user can still specify an emtpy network with
--empty-network

Change-Id: Ia00a16ec5bc5b51af9f2ba10f12b896edf57bfff

[{'created': '2012-11-05 19:41:51.000000000', 'message': "generalize the libvirt network volume driver

Rename the internal attribute source_host to source_name as that better
describes its actual usage, and add new source_host and source_port
attributes that translate to the equivalent libvirt XML elements.

This is useful for example for usage with NBD, which requires the
hostname and port when used through libvirt, or would allow to
specify a sheepdog daemon that doesn't run on the local host on
the default port.

Implements blueprint better-libvirt-network-volume-support

Change-Id: I4e1340045e1ebb9c19324dd55f569d983c3bf65b
"}]
commit_message:
generalize the libvirt network volume driver

Rename the internal attribute source_host to source_name as that better
describes its actual usage, and add new source_host and source_port
attributes that translate to the equivalent libvirt XML elements.

This is useful for example for usage with NBD, which requires the
hostname and port when used through libvirt, or would allow to
specify a sheepdog daemon that doesn't run on the local host on
the default port.

Implements blueprint better-libvirt-network-volume-support

Change-Id: I4e1340045e1ebb9c19324dd55f569d983c3bf65b

I know that tox doesn't run pep8 on the tests, but having those long lines makes it really hard to read the diff on my relatively narrow screen."}, {'account_id': 6186, 'date': '2012-11-13 21:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 21:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-13 22:40:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-11-13 23:13:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm pretty sure reverse delimiters aren't going to work, since it tries to set the marker to something larger than the next delimited value.  Actually that might cause an infinite loop, if I'm thinking about it correctly.

Is this a change to the API that we want to support forever and force on everyone who might want to implement a swift backend in the future?  It might be, I'm just curious."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-13 23:53:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I tried it in a terminal; by setting marker to the last returned value, everything worked as I expected. I set my container_listing_limit to 4 and uploaded 10 objects, and: http://paste.openstack.org/show/LZAWqVEhxHZ1OY6XWFTv/

Was that your objection, or am I misunderstanding?

As for whether or not we want this, I want it so that I can simplify some of the object-versioning stuff. In particular, versioned-object deletion has to walk the entire versions container just to find the last object in it. With this patch, that becomes one request with reverse=yes&limit=1; no data is wasted.'}, {'account_id': 6186, 'date': '2012-11-14 00:56:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I believe he's talking about these lines: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/db.py#L1122
https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/db.py#L1126

A bug would happen when using using path or using delimiter+prefix. I believe tests need to be written that go through those code paths with the reverse option. I'll find time to work on that tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-11-14 01:18:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yeah, that.  Once it finds a subdir on a prefix/delimiter query, it tries to construct a marker that sorts after all subdir contents to jump past it.  I'd guess you'll have to either disable path/delimiter on reverse queries, or branch that code to construct a marker that sorts before any subdir contents."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-14 01:27:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

I need to think about subdirs + delimiters, then take another look.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:20:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I see what Michael is talking about. This change doesn't handle reversals with pseudo-folder stuff.

Here's an example:

torgobook:doc (master +)$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" "http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/doc"
source/_ga/layout.html
source/_static/basic.css
source/_static/default.css
source/_static/tweaks.css
source/_theme/layout.html
source/_theme/theme.conf
source/account.rst
source/admin_guide.rst
[...]

As you can see, I uploaded the contents of Swift's "doc" directory into a container cleverly named "doc".

Now, a query:

torgobook:doc (master +)$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" "http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/doc?limit=2&prefix=source/_static/&delimiter=/"
source/_static/basic.css
source/_static/default.css

Reverse it:

torgobook:doc (master +)$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" "http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/doc?limit=2&prefix=source/_static/&delimiter=/&reverse=yes"
source/_static/basic.css
source/_static/default.css

There's the problem. I expect to get "source/_static/tweaks.css" followed by "source/_static/default.css".'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:22:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Gerrit ate my formatting. Here's the mangled bits again, but hopefully less mangled:

    torgobook:doc (master +)$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" "http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/doc?limit=2&prefix=source/_static/&delimiter=/"
    source/_static/basic.css
    source/_static/default.css

    Reverse the query:

    torgobook:doc (master +)$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" "http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/doc?limit=2&prefix=source/_static/&delimiter=/&reverse=yes"
    source/_static/basic.css
    source/_static/default.css

There's the problem. I expect to get "source/_static/tweaks.css" followed by "source/_static/default.css".'}, {'account_id': 6186, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Abandoned

I will revisit this change. There's way more places where ordering is assumed."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-14 18:49:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I don't think you've got that much further to go.

The main problem with prefix queries is that the result set coming out of sqlite is only bounded on the left.

That is, given a container with objects

a/1
a/2
a/3
b/1
b/2
b/3

if you query with a prefix of "a/" and a marker of "a/2", then what you get out of the database is everything lexicographically greater than a/2, namely a/3, b/1, b/2, and b/3. Then, results not starting with "a/" are thrown away in Python.

Were you to filter the results in the DB, then you'd have a result set that's bounded on both sides, and so the descending-sort would work as intended.

I hacked up a patch (http://paste.openstack.org/raw/IuSg5bAfP3vaVkvPRUyy/) that does the DB-level filtering, and it seemed to make things work as expected when I prodded at it with curl.

Now, things I did not consider in that diff include:
 
 * unit tests
 * the code building a new marker with "marker = name[:end] + chr(ord(delimiter) + 1)"
 * does the sqlite that ships w/Lucid support the functions used?

However, I think you're closer than you think. :)'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-11-14 19:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I'm pretty sure that patch would cause prefix queries that don't return at least "limit" results to scan all the way to the end of the database looking for more.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-11-14 20:06:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You could probably implement prefix with LIKE instead of substr and have it use the index to limit results.'}, {'account_id': 6186, 'date': '2012-11-14 21:14:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored

According to http://www.sqlite.org/lang_expr.html glob might be the thing we'd want to use since that is case sensitive.

I'll un-abandon this change since it's probably ~4 amendments away from good.

TODO:
* Unit tests that test edge-cases/hit all code paths
* Address the two lines that create a new marker one char away (to avoid scanning files in pseudo-paths we already have) that look like this: "marker = name[:end] + chr(ord(delimiter) + 1)"
* Evaluate the sqlite query explain'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-22 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-22 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Initial Implementation of reverse-object-listing

Adds a reverse param to object listings which reverses the listing
order to descending. Adds a unit test verifying basic functionality.

Change-Id: I09c0e1c471e9fb870933679dc75039fe403c3f3b
DocImpact
Implements: blueprint  reverse-object-listing

'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-11-08 00:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Thanks for the patch!

The problem with this is that it isn't backwards compatible in any way. Yes, this is a valid bug, but this fix breaks installs that are not Quantal. :( For instance: 12.04's node package places a node binary in the location that is being removed in this patch."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-11-08 00:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

This is unacceptable for 2 reasons:

  1. This breaks it for all versions of node which still *do* install a script called "node", including 12.04 which is the LTS.

  2. We're bundling the LESS script *unmodified* from upstream. I'm not open to changing that. The upstream still uses the "node" script name.

Honestly I think this is a problem between the Ubuntu package maintainer for Node and the developers of LESS.

That said, other solution ideas here are welcome.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add volume bootable information to api response

If there is any glance metadata associated with a volume, we'll consider
the volume bootable. This will return the information for both /volumes
and /detail calls.

blueprint list-bootable-volumes

Change-Id: Id9dbe5cb648be62fb19bb8bd6a97d8eab05ec25a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 12:58:48.000000000', 'message': "don't explode if a 413 didn't set Retry-After

We use 413 error code not only for temporary out of memory
conditions but also for over quota issues. These kinds of
requests don't set a Retry-After header, but the code assumed
that was a valid key, thus exploding on a KeyError. Issue
caught in looking at tempest traces.

Fixes bug #1079387

Change-Id: Id406ab0799a35220b189b2e5292be092eb821ec5
"}]
commit_message:
don't explode if a 413 didn't set Retry-After

We use 413 error code not only for temporary out of memory
conditions but also for over quota issues. These kinds of
requests don't set a Retry-After header, but the code assumed
that was a valid key, thus exploding on a KeyError. Issue
caught in looking at tempest traces.

Fixes bug #1079387

Change-Id: Id406ab0799a35220b189b2e5292be092eb821ec5

commit_message:
Configure guest CPU model with libvirt+KVM

Document how to control the guest CPU model when using libvirt+kvm.

Docs are based on this OpenStack wiki page by Daniel Berrange
http://wiki.openstack.org/LibvirtXMLCPUModel

This functionality was introduced in the Folsom release.

Change-Id: Ic9a82f7f9d477f68b3bfd27f0312e46e434f0651

commit_message:
Cleaning up volume driver paths

Moved all the remaining drivers under
cinder.volume.drivers. Updated the tests with
the new module paths and add backwards compatibilty
for the existing paths.

Implements bp driver-cleanup

Change-Id: I7673b5209cc072ac859d7d32cdeed2e7a17331e8

commit_message:
Removes the xensm driver

This code does not work, and is slowly being replaced by
alternative XenServer specific drivers.

Fixes LP bug #1077011

Change-Id: I1af92ecdbb49a57a0ff4c05a70d77bcb69958cb2

The default value ('nova.virt.connection.get_connection') was mistakenly removed in:
I337795f6956050b398c39a8476e3c1e2b689c470

Without the default value installations that have been using
connection_type for the last two releases to set compute flavor start
with no manager set.

Fix bug 1081836

Change-Id: I5ea33fc57fa10b1c69a8d3c82f0a2a477fbbbe9f
"}]
commit_message:
Re-add compute_driver default value

The default value ('nova.virt.connection.get_connection') was mistakenly removed in:
I337795f6956050b398c39a8476e3c1e2b689c470

Without the default value installations that have been using
connection_type for the last two releases to set compute flavor start
with no manager set.

Fix bug 1081836

Change-Id: I5ea33fc57fa10b1c69a8d3c82f0a2a477fbbbe9f

The path of the disk for snapshotting LXC instance is debugged.
Also, virt_dom.managedSave(0) and self._create_domain(domain=virt_dom)
are not called for LXC instance, because they are supported by libvirt.

Change-Id: Idf8275a0222b2eb289e16dd245f7721e17fce21d
(cherry picked from commit b60646965de26974f8a8b81f6e43b72a6c8d44f5)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes bug Snapshotting LXC instance fails

Fixes bug 1058273.

The path of the disk for snapshotting LXC instance is debugged.
Also, virt_dom.managedSave(0) and self._create_domain(domain=virt_dom)
are not called for LXC instance, because they are supported by libvirt.

Change-Id: Idf8275a0222b2eb289e16dd245f7721e17fce21d
(cherry picked from commit b60646965de26974f8a8b81f6e43b72a6c8d44f5)

[{'created': '2012-11-21 22:45:40.000000000', 'message': "Move compute_driver into nova.virt.driver

Commit 9102f80 moved compute_driver from nova.compute.manager into
nova.config. We're trying to get away from so many global options,
so where to put it?

The config option is used for two things - loading the driver and,
in a bunch of random places, checking if it matches a specific
value.

It seems to make perfect to sense to encapsulate both as functions
in nova.virt.driver and move the option there.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I28a71df5b682c6bd381401f63da49d91fb187125
"}]
commit_message:
Move compute_driver into nova.virt.driver

Commit 9102f80 moved compute_driver from nova.compute.manager into
nova.config. We're trying to get away from so many global options,
so where to put it?

The config option is used for two things - loading the driver and,
in a bunch of random places, checking if it matches a specific
value.

It seems to make perfect to sense to encapsulate both as functions
in nova.virt.driver and move the option there.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I28a71df5b682c6bd381401f63da49d91fb187125

commit_message:
Re-organize compute opts a bit

There are over 20 opts declared in nova.compute.manager and they're
a disorganized jumbled of miscellaneous stuff. Put some order on them
by grouping them into misc, intervals, timeouts and "running deleted".
Also, alphabetically sort the misc options.

Not perfect, but much easier to make sense of them now.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I87c514de6b4432101aa7cc35789e2cb1d7e6a150

Hook up region_name argument

Connect the --os-region-name option passed through the CLI
to the call to service_catalog.url_for.

Fixes bug 1080739.

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-11-19 23:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm totally in support of seeing this fixed, but there's a better way to do it:

  1. All API calls should be wrapped in a try/except and use horizon.exceptions.handle in the except block.

  2. The horizon.exceptions.check_message function exists to handle just this type of case. The string returned by Nova's API actually includes discernable words: "Instance Type with name <name> already exists. (HTTP 409)" So we can detect this specific error and return a friendlier message.

See the code here for an example of those two in action:

https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/volumes/tables.py#L45'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2012-11-20 10:00:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-20 10:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Return a friendly error at flavor creation

When trying to create a flavor with an Id/Name that is already in use, the
operation fails and no error message is being displayed

Change-Id: I92db8b52bc4e63e5e5ce4d90169944e484baeddd
Fixes: bug #1079155

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-21 04:35:34.000000000', 'message': 'Adds transitional deprecation code for old dashboard names.

This code allows users who upgrade from Folsom to Grizzly to
continue using their old settings file until H.

The code is in the settings file because it must be run prior
to the modules listed in INSTALLED_APPS being loaded into the
python path.

Fixes bug 1071444.

Change-Id: I7ac30b731be3cdc7513e3d6bc34d624963bbea9b
'}]
commit_message:
Adds transitional deprecation code for old dashboard names.

This code allows users who upgrade from Folsom to Grizzly to
continue using their old settings file until H.

The code is in the settings file because it must be run prior
to the modules listed in INSTALLED_APPS being loaded into the
python path.

Fixes bug 1071444.

Change-Id: I7ac30b731be3cdc7513e3d6bc34d624963bbea9b

commit_message:
No longer import db_api while parsing db __init__.

The db_api field of reddwarf/db/__init__.py was grabbed by importing a
module using utils.import_object. The imported module was always the
sqlalchemy api module, which is nested under the file that imports it,
which caused import errors in multiple contexts. This commit changes
every use of db_api to call a function to load it first, which seems
to fix these problems.

Change-Id: I9515efe02831b521d7f14674e0a2913e476b207d
Fixes: bug #1080706

commit_message:
Get db session from the context.

The aim is to use a single sqlalchemy session for an RPC request.

The context object passed to EngineAPI methods is actually an RpcContext
which contains the same data as the RequestContext. The @request_context
decorator turns this back into a RequestContext which can now have other
behaviours added to it.

RequestContext now has a lazy loaded session attribute.

Save calls on created entities need to be passed the shared session.

Change-Id: Ied4e66deaca205362b84fb698f75cc872886607d

Adds missing index migrations by instance/status.

Adds an index for use with the migration_get_by_instance_and_status
SQL API call.

commit_message:
improve session handling around instance_ methods

clean up session usage in some of the instance_* methods:
  instance_destroy
  instance_get_all_hung_in_rebooting
  instance_(add|remove)_security_group
  instance_info_cache_(get|update|delete)

also remove instance_info_cache_create since this is not used

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: I33913dae3bc28e05d856d951454440a12616706e

'}, {'created': '2012-11-09 14:27:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add XenAPINFSDriver

Related to xenapi-storage-manager-nfs

As xensm was not pulled to Cinder, this change shows an implementation
example for using an NFS export for volumes. This change contains the
volume create and delete functions, as a minimal set of functionality.
The connection information structure is compatible with the previous
xensm implementation.

Activate the driver with the following configuration entries in
cinder.conf:

volume_driver=cinder.volume.xenapi_sm.XenAPINFSDriver
xenapi_connection_url=http://<yourxenserver>
xenapi_connection_username=root
xenapi_connection_password=<secret>
xenapi_nfs_server=<nfs_server_address>
xenapi_nfs_serverpath=/exported_catalog

Change-Id: Ieaf077f540fc026c5bc37f2e3eb9d48fb96d0b74

example for using an NFS export for volumes. This change contains the
volume create and delete functions, as a minimal set of functionality.
The connection information structure is compatible with the previous
xensm implementation.

Activate the driver with the following configuration entries in
cinder.conf:

volume_driver=cinder.volume.xenapi_sm.XenAPINFSDriver
xenapi_connection_url=http://<yourxenserver>
xenapi_connection_username=root
xenapi_connection_password=<secret>
xenapi_nfs_server=<nfs_server_address>
xenapi_nfs_serverpath=/exported_catalog

Change-Id: Ieaf077f540fc026c5bc37f2e3eb9d48fb96d0b74
'}]
commit_message:
Add XenAPINFSDriver

Related to blueprint xenapi-storage-manager-nfs

As xensm was not pulled to Cinder, this change shows an implementation
example for using an NFS export for volumes. This change contains the
volume create and delete functions, as a minimal set of functionality.
The connection information structure is compatible with the previous
xensm implementation.

Activate the driver with the following configuration entries in
cinder.conf:

volume_driver=cinder.volume.xenapi_sm.XenAPINFSDriver
xenapi_connection_url=http://<yourxenserver>
xenapi_connection_username=root
xenapi_connection_password=<secret>
xenapi_nfs_server=<nfs_server_address>
xenapi_nfs_serverpath=/exported_catalog

Change-Id: Ieaf077f540fc026c5bc37f2e3eb9d48fb96d0b74

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-21 15:59:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix wait_for_deleted function in SmokeTests.

Fixes the wait_for_not_running function in smoketests/base.py so
that it short circuits when an instance ID is deleted rather than
waits 60 seconds (the timeout). Previously this function had
two problems:

 1) It used Boto's instance.update() instead of instance.update(validate=True).
 Since update() returns returns quietly if no data about the instance was
 returned (aka the instance has been deleted) it effectively made this
 function almost always wait for the timeout (60 seconds). This makes the
 tests take about a minute longer than they need to unless #2 below
 occurs...

 2) It also introduced a race condition in that... if hit just right
 the instance.state would get set to 'terminated'. Which would cause
 the loop to short circuit. This might seem correct at first glance but
 in fact causes intermittent failures in some of the netadmin tests
 because security groups can't be deleted if a running (or exiting)
 instance is still assigned to them. In fact wait_for_not_running
 was added to guard against just this in the first place!

Also, renames the base.wait_for_not_running function to be
called wait_for_deleted (that is what we are really doing here)

Change-Id: I4486995a7d9028d876366e8d7a2c845520319b86
"}]
commit_message:
Fix wait_for_deleted function in SmokeTests.

Fixes the wait_for_not_running function in smoketests/base.py so
that it short circuits when an instance ID is deleted rather than
waits 60 seconds (the timeout). Previously this function had
two problems:

 1) It used Boto's instance.update() instead of instance.update(validate=True).
 Since update() returns returns quietly if no data about the instance was
 returned (aka the instance has been deleted) it effectively made this
 function almost always wait for the timeout (60 seconds). This makes the
 tests take about a minute longer than they need to unless #2 below
 occurs...

 2) It also introduced a race condition in that... if hit just right
 the instance.state would get set to 'terminated'. Which would cause
 the loop to short circuit. This might seem correct at first glance but
 in fact causes intermittent failures in some of the netadmin tests
 because security groups can't be deleted if a running (or exiting)
 instance is still assigned to them. In fact wait_for_not_running
 was added to guard against just this in the first place!

Also, renames the base.wait_for_not_running function to be
called wait_for_deleted (that is what we are really doing here)

Change-Id: I4486995a7d9028d876366e8d7a2c845520319b86

commit_message:
Make cooperative reader always support read()

glance.common.utils.CooperativeReader provides eventlet-friendly
cooperation on top of backends that support either read() or __iter__().
However, in the case of backends that only support __iter__(), such as
images returned by store.get(...), read() is not defined. This patch
adds read() in all cases.

Fixes bug 1057322.

Change-Id: I67d9b3e4d93fbefd7eeaf7cfc947ab635fe09534

commit_message:
Allow for not running pep8.

Its not always wanted to run pep8 so we should have
a flag that can be used to disable it so that people
who do not want to run it can accomplish this.

Fixes: bug 1080907

Change-Id: I7f9dedbc7eca8421e0acf58e478c105f8b8de0c9

commit_message:
Boot from volume without image supplied

Allow for booting instances from volume without the image parameter
supplied. This change is related to the change
I530760cfaa5eb0cae590c7383e0840c6b3f896b9
in opnestack/nova. It allows for boot to work with no image supplied
to accommodate booting from volumes only.

It also makes it possible to interpret show servers that were started
without images, so from volumes only

Change-Id: I5ba9b0f35a5084aa91eca260f46cac83b8b6591e

commit_message:
Added --extra-opts to the nova ssh command

This will allow for remote command execution and advanced ssh options
like portforwarding and connection sharing.
The goal is to support ssh commands like
nova ssh fe55adc9-cb1e-44a4-bd36-6a537b238172 --extra-opts='-NfnMS ~/.ssh/master-fe55adc9-cb1e-44a4-bd36-6a537b238172'
and ssh fe55adc9-cb1e-44a4-bd36-6a537b238172 --extra-opts='-t "sudo puppet agent --test"'
This will alow easier scripting of the cli... It is not intended
however to replace using the nova python api. Therefore I kept it simple.

Change-Id: Icce811caf637fc92c6d6374bfb846ea9525a7e05

'}, {'created': '2012-11-09 07:48:14.000000000', 'message': 'fix hypervisor-servers for hypervisors without servers

commit_message:
fix hypervisor-servers for hypervisors without servers

At the moment hypervisor-servers throws an AttributeError for
hypervisors with no assigned instances. This patch checks first
if there are assigned instances before looping through them to
avoid the exception.

fixes bug 1076435

Change-Id: I504e3f234fd041325b63295fab77f9ed3f704db0

the currently used tenant should be used.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 10:13:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova client support for nova-manage service command

Implements the one workitem of blueprint apis-for-nova-manage

This add three CLI (service-list/sevice-enable/service-diabel) in
nova-client.

So we can use:
"nova service-list" like "nova-manage service list" with two optional
parameters. Show a list of all running services. Filter by host and
service name.

"nova service-enable hostname servicename" like "nova-manage service
enable hostname servicename". It will enable the service specified by
hostname and serviename.

"nova service-disable hostname servicename" like "nova-manage service
diable hostname servicename". It will disable the service specified by
hostname and serviename.

This patch depends on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15206/

Change-Id: I01d4cee4ef95c1783f6181f8b840244e748387e5
'}]
commit_message:
Add nova client support for nova-manage service command

Implements the one workitem of blueprint apis-for-nova-manage

This add three CLI (service-list/sevice-enable/service-diabel) in
nova-client.

So we can use:
"nova service-list" like "nova-manage service list" with two optional
parameters. Show a list of all running services. Filter by host and
service name.

"nova service-enable hostname servicename" like "nova-manage service
enable hostname servicename". It will enable the service specified by
hostname and serviename.

"nova service-disable hostname servicename" like "nova-manage service
diable hostname servicename". It will disable the service specified by
hostname and serviename.

This patch depends on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15206/

Change-Id: I01d4cee4ef95c1783f6181f8b840244e748387e5

commit_message:
Add db table for Glance Metadata

This commit implements the blueprint
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/retain-glance-metadata-for-billing

It creates the new table volume_glance_metadata in the cinder
database, provides the CRUD methods for it, and populates the table
when a volume or snapshot is created from a Glance image.

Patch set 2: remove superflous line

Patch set 3: Fix incorrect column types in sqlalchemy/models.py

Patch set 4: Define exception class GlanceMetadataExists

Change-Id: I8f98f6eaae005a33bfd49cea783774407b7aa120

commit_message:
Move sql options to nova.db.sqlalchemy.session

With a few minor exceptions, the sql config options are used solely
within the nova.db.sqlalchemy.session module so it makes sense to move
their declaration into that module.

Change-Id: Iea9c2bb000cd713b01750ab3e796132ebeaa4ca8

commit_message:
Add debug logging to disk mount modules

To assist in troubleshooting file injection code, add some
LOG.debug() statements to the nova/virt/disk/mount/*.py
modules

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I75214145ef489a29a58f69abe6195ff01f36153c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove the libguestfs disk mount API implementation

The nova.virt.disk.mount.guestfs.API impl is now unused,
since there is a dedicated libguestfs impl of the VFS
APIs. It can thus be removed

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I6c19e38f23b056d770bfb93e21fa3e64ac179a42
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: Remove img_handlers config parameter usage
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-15 13:34:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/1/check/gate-nova-merge/12112 : SUCCESS

"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-11-15 13:54:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-15 14:22:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-merge/12118 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-docs/7851 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/13161 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-python26/9302 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-python27/9371 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/18605 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/2957 : FAILURE (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-15 15:08:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Very vice refactoring!

So to summarise the new structure:

inject_data()
    fmt = 'raw' or 'qcow2'
    fs = vfs.VFS.instance_for_image(image, fmt)
        return guestfs_if_importable or localfs (..fmt..)
    ...

setup_container()
    _disk_image.mount()
    fmt = 'raw' or 'qcow2'
    mounter = mount.Mount.instance_for_format(.fmt..)
        return loop or nbd
    ...

So a possible issue for the new inject_data() is
a performance penalty introduced by using guestfs
if installed. Not too bad I suppose, as it can be
uninstalled, though libguestfs could be being used
independently of openstack which would be problematic.
This flow also assumes that libguestfs can handle all
images that qemu-nbd can which might not be the case
given the extra introspection that libguestfs does.

The new setup_container() seems a bit more problematic.
Not using libguestfs here means that qemu-nbd is assumed to
work. That's not the case on RHEL based systems for example,
and while this combination is limited to the LXC case,
the qcow config param is not.
Also we've seen some cirros images that qemu-nbd fails on, but libguestsfs is fine with.

There the main edge cases I can remember at the moment,
which was the basis of the current scheme of trying
in sequence loop -> nbd -> guestfs"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-11-15 15:19:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> So a possible issue for the new inject_data() is a performance penalty introduced by
> using guestfs if installed. Not too bad I suppose, as it can be uninstalled, though
> libguestfs could be being used independently of openstack which would be problematic.
> This flow also assumes that libguestfs can handle all images that qemu-nbd can which
> might not be the case given the extra introspection that libguestfs does.

In my testing, the only noticable performance penalty from use of libguestfs occurs when it has to build the initial appliance image. After that point, the performance differences are negligable when placed in the context of everything else that is done to boot a guest. From a security POV, if we have libguestfs available, we should never consider using anything else.

Do you have any examples of cases where qemu-nbd works and libguestfs does not ? We are in complete control of the OS introspection code now, so if there are scenarios it does not handle correctly, we can now fix them (which was not possible when the FUSE program was in charge of introspection).

> The new setup_container() seems a bit more problematic. Not using libguestfs here means that
> qemu-nbd is assumed to work. That's not the case on RHEL based systems for example, and while
> this combination is limited to the LXC case, the qcow config param is not. Also we've seen
> some cirros images that qemu-nbd fails on, but libguestsfs is fine with.

If you have chosen to use LXC for your instance, I think it is very wrong to have a KVM instance running behind the scenes to handle filesystems, because it is throwing away the primary point of LXC, which is its low footprint. If there are scenarios that don't work with qemu-nbd which are important for LXC, then I think we need to address that in the NBD setup code, and not fallback to libguestfs for LXC.

> There the main edge cases I can remember at the moment, which was the basis of
> the current scheme of trying in sequence loop -> nbd -> guestfs

Killing off this auto-fallback behaviour is a strong desire of mine because it is masking/discarding errors which should really not be ignored. I eventually want to get to a place where we can mark disk images such that file injection failure is considered a fatal startup issue."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-11-15 15:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-15 15:53:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-merge/12132 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-docs/7865 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-pep8/13175 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-python26/9316 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-python27/9385 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/18624 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16178/3/check/gate-nova-pylint/2971 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-15 16:18:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> In my testing, the only noticable performance penalty
> from use of libguestfs occurs when it has to build the
> initial appliance image. After that point, the
> performance differences are negligable when placed in
> the context of everything else that is done to boot a
> guest. From a security POV, if we have libguestfs
> available, we should never consider using anything else

There is overhead in firing up the VM in both mem and time.
Again not too bad I suppose.  From my measurements a while
back, an initial run was 5s and 2s after the appliance
image was built.

> Do you have any examples of cases where qemu-nbd works
> and libguestfs does not ? We are in complete control of
> the OS introspection code now, so if there are
> scenarios it does not handle correctly, we can now fix
> them (which was not possible when the FUSE program was
> in charge of introspection).

We currently default the libvirt partition to 1
even for libguestsfs, because some older versions of
libguestfs (as of 1 year ago) have problems identifying
partitionless ttylinux images for example.
Having greater control of the introspection is encouraging.


> If you have chosen to use LXC for your instance, I
> think it is very wrong to have a KVM instance running
> behind the scenes to handle filesystems, because it is
> throwing away the primary point of LXC, which is its
> low footprint. If there are scenarios that don't work
> with qemu-nbd which are important for LXC, then I think
> we need to address that in the NBD setup code, and not
> fallback to libguestfs for LXC.

libguestfs might be needed to mount more complex images
(with LVM structures for example), and it might still
provide lower overhead than a full blown VM,
but fair point.  Are there any cases where libguestfs
might work, but a full blown VM would not (like on
ARM for example)?

> Killing off this auto-fallback behaviour is a strong
> desire of mine because it is masking/discarding errors
> which should really not be ignored. I eventually want
> to get to a place where we can mark disk images such
> that file injection failure is considered a fatal
> startup issue.

It was discussed a bit on the list that the policy
should be at the moment to warn about failure to
inject any of (key, net, metadata, admin_password),
while failure to inject specified files, does
currently result in a startup error."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-11-15 16:41:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> There is overhead in firing up the VM in both mem and time. Again not too bad I suppose. From my measurements a while back, an initial run was 5s and 2s after the appliance image was built.

I think 3s is a reasonably typically overhead for launching the appliance when cached. That might sound alot if considered in isolation, but you have to put in the context of everything else that takes place. Booting the actual guest OS can take anywhere in the order 30-60 seconds. Nova's own network filtering setup takes non-trivial amount of time. Likewise QEMU BIOS overhead if loading kernel+initrd can take 1-2 seconds.

So we're arguing over adding a few % points to the overall end-to-end startup time. I don't think that is enough to counteract significantly improved host security characteristics and feature capabilities of libguestfs vs the nbd/loop solutiuons.

> We currently default the libvirt partition to 1 even for libguestsfs, because some older versions of libguestfs (as of 1 year ago) have problems identifying partitionless ttylinux images for example. Having greater control of the introspection is encouraging.

I did not notice that current code had hardcoded the partition number. The new code ignores the partition number. I'd like to think we can make it work with partitionless images, without having to disable inspection by default.

> libguestfs might be needed to mount more complex images (with LVM structures for example), and it might still provide 
> lower overhead than a full blown VM, but fair point. Are there any cases where libguestfs might work, but a full
> blown VM would not (like on ARM for example)?

IMHO supporting complex schemes like LVM with LXC is a solution in search of a problem. I just don't think it is sensible to be using KVM to provide LVM support for LXC, even though it may be technically possible.


> It was discussed a bit on the list that the policy should be at the moment to warn about failure to inject any of (key, net, metadata, admin_password), while failure to inject specified files, does currently result in a startup error.

That does not appear to be how it is currently implemented. The libvirt driver.py code does

            try:
                disk.inject_data(injection_path,
                                 key, net, metadata, admin_pass, files,
                                 partition=target_partition,
                                 use_cow=CONF.use_cow_images)

            except Exception as e:
                # This could be a windows image, or a vmdk format disk
                LOG.warn(_('Ignoring error injecting data into image '
                           '%(img_id)s (%(e)s)') % locals(),
                         instance=instance)

ie, *all* errors are merely logged & then ignored. I don't see anything that causes file injection to be considered a hard startup error."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-15 17:44:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I think 3s is a reasonably typically overhead for launching the appliance when cached. That might sound a lot if considered in isolation, but you have to put in the context of everything else that takes place. Booting the actual guest OS can take anywhere in the order 30-60 seconds. Nova's own network filtering setup takes non-trivial amount of time. Likewise QEMU BIOS overhead if loading kernel+initrd can take 1-2 seconds.

> So we're arguing over adding a few % points to the overall end-to-end startup time. I don't think that is enough to counteract significantly improved host security characteristics and feature capabilities of libguestfs vs the nbd/loop solutiuons.

Not arguing, just quantifying :)
I agree libguestfs is generally better here

> That [specific file injection error bubbling up] does not appear to be how it is currently implemented.

Drats I messed that up in:
Ib66d327e745593cf1e5897470750d609b2a58980
I'll fix that up..."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-20 20:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-11-20 21:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@pbrady: FYI I have fixed the libguestfs VFS code to correctly honour the partition settings as it does now'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-11-20 22:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 12:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'Remove img_handlers config parameter usage

Now that the only disk code requiring host filesystem
mounts is the LXC filesystem setup, the img_handlers
config parameter is an solution looking for a purpose.
For any disk image format we can categorically say
whether it should be mounted using loop or qemu-nbd
mount impls. There is no desire to use libguestfs FUSE
for mounting LXC disk images, since users of LXC do
not want a huge KVM process alongside every container!
Move the mount class choice logic into the mount API,
by creating new methods

  nova.virt.disk.mount.API.instance_for_format()
  nova.virt.disk.mount.API.instance_for_device()

and then call these from nova.virt.disk.API code

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I088b5debdf62d4a9a6b4521eee68cd4757f2ff42
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove img_handlers config parameter usage

Now that the only disk code requiring host filesystem
mounts is the LXC filesystem setup, the img_handlers
config parameter is an solution looking for a purpose.
For any disk image format we can categorically say
whether it should be mounted using loop or qemu-nbd
mount impls. There is no desire to use libguestfs FUSE
for mounting LXC disk images, since users of LXC do
not want a huge KVM process alongside every container!
Move the mount class choice logic into the mount API,
by creating new methods

  nova.virt.disk.mount.API.instance_for_format()
  nova.virt.disk.mount.API.instance_for_device()

and then call these from nova.virt.disk.API code

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I088b5debdf62d4a9a6b4521eee68cd4757f2ff42
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Convert file injection code to use the VFS APIs

Remove the requirement to mount disk images on the host
filesystem for file injection, by switching over to use
the new VFS APIs. The mount code is now solely used for
setting up LXC disk images

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I1335bf7a8266d3d1d410a66538969f1213766cb9
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introduce a VFS implementation backed by the libguestfs APIs

This implements the VFS APIs using the libguestfs Python APIs.
This removes the need to map the virtual disk image into the
host filesystem, and thus avoids potential symlink attacks
from the guest filesystem. It also performs better than the
libguestfs FUSE module

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I3202ec9479f22aa1ae461cab24968e54be1642c1
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introduce a VFS implementation mapped to the host filesystem

This implements the VFS APIs by using the nova.virt.disk.mount.Mount
APIs to map the virtual disk image into the host filesystem. This
only uses the loop/qemu-nbd mount implementations, since there will
be a dedicated libguestfs VFS API avoiding the need for the guestfs
mount impl

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: Ifeb04770d55a3d1627db807322d57c0bedfc59cb
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Use reddwarf instead of reddwarf_lite

This codebase used to be reddwarf_lite, it is now stackforge/reddwarf,
let's make sure naming conventions follow suit

Fixes bug 1081321

Change-Id: I9d56a1ec5274f49285992a2264b0e6d7a2a6c27f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-21 11:57:35.000000000', 'message': 'Stop network.api import on network import

The nova.network.__init__.py was importing the network.api
automatically at import time. This was leading to some silly
workarounds (for example in nova/virt/firewall.py) involving
late importing nova.network to stop circular imports.

It is also causing issues with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/13007/
because quantum api needs to import a flag from network manager
which is causing a circular import.

This fixes the issue by moving to use the code from volume_api
which only imports the api class when the method is called. It cleans
up the tests that were stubbing out network.API and also removes
the unneeded workarounds.

Change-Id: I4c9b372d078ab4398e797335a8de5e9e1077e31f
'}]
commit_message:
Stop network.api import on network import

The nova.network.__init__.py was importing the network.api
automatically at import time. This was leading to some silly
workarounds (for example in nova/virt/firewall.py) involving
late importing nova.network to stop circular imports.

It is also causing issues with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/13007/
because quantum api needs to import a flag from network manager
which is causing a circular import.

This fixes the issue by moving to use the code from volume_api
which only imports the api class when the method is called. It cleans
up the tests that were stubbing out network.API and also removes
the unneeded workarounds.

Change-Id: I4c9b372d078ab4398e797335a8de5e9e1077e31f

heat engine retrieve credentials every periodic task interval

Avoid saving a session context, instead retrieve the DB stored
credentials for every periodic task trigger, and create a new
session context for each periodic event

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-21 13:22:04.000000000', 'message': "heat engine Add admin flag to dbapi stack_get

Add a flag to the stack_get dbapi call, defaulted to False,
which allows us to specify that the admin context is being used
hence we don't want tenant-scoping condition applied.
This is needed to allow the admin context to retrieve stored
credentials per-stack (e.g for the periodic per-stack tasks)

Change-Id: I55e307b7940f7da13bd169271744e80d95ea0bd9
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
heat engine Add admin flag to dbapi stack_get

Add a flag to the stack_get dbapi call, defaulted to False,
which allows us to specify that the admin context is being used
hence we don't want tenant-scoping condition applied.
This is needed to allow the admin context to retrieve stored
credentials per-stack (e.g for the periodic per-stack tasks)

Change-Id: I55e307b7940f7da13bd169271744e80d95ea0bd9
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
api: replace minified files by complete version

Minified files are problematic at least for Debian because it's not free
according to the DFSG. So let's replace them with full versions.

This fixes bug #1078788

Change-Id: Id401feea7ed7d0a7861a44f9ccc294615617f928
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'created': '2012-11-21 10:53:53.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor - do not update "architecture" twice in dictionary "base_options" during instance creation.

During the instance creation a dictionary of instance characteristics (base_options) is created in nova.compute.api._create_instance where
"architecture" is defined looking into image[properties]. Then "architecture" entry is updated to the same value in nova.compute.api._populate_instance_for_create if defined or it removes the 'Unknown' value for this key.

This patch removes the unnecessary "architecture" update.

Change-Id: Iaa3e01277a5d3b2c71afdf2b0fca201d2d094555
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor - do not update "architecture" twice in dictionary "base_options" during instance creation.

During the instance creation a dictionary of instance characteristics (base_options) is created in nova.compute.api._create_instance where
"architecture" is defined looking into image[properties]. Then "architecture" entry is updated to the same value in nova.compute.api._populate_instance_for_create if defined or it removes the 'Unknown' value for this key.

This patch removes the unnecessary "architecture" update.

Change-Id: Iaa3e01277a5d3b2c71afdf2b0fca201d2d094555

commit_message:
Used auth_token middleware from keystoneclient.

The auth_token middleware was moved from keystone to keystoneclient.

Fixed the bug 1080990.

Change-Id: I424489b73e420546df96a52f639d0ee1c8ee6287

commit_message:
Eliminates simultaneous schedule race.

Keeps host state in memory so multiple schedule attempts use the
up-to-date values that may have been modified by another greenthread.

Fixes bug 1073956

Change-Id: I69fdd9b46bde6b7408c501c42a6ef3b6dd92bbc2
(cherry picked from commit 94560ab57d9fc23673f42017e6f2a78cb2b66b7a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 09:11:15.000000000', 'message': 'This fixes bug 1074215.

The bug reports "Tenant ID is a required parameter of user-role-add, but this command display is optional parameter.". Simpley added "required=True" to the corresponding file.

commit_message:
Fixes bug 1074215

This sets up "tenant-id" as required parameter for "user-role-add".

Change-Id: If4c3c91b34878558784213489d7a5fc08da36985

subject: Switch to using generate_uuid from openstack common
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-13 19:45:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Like utils.gen_uuid(), I don't understand why uuidutils.generate_uuid() exists.

It adds an extra layer of indirection (which should be discouraged) and at the cost of being longer to type than 'str(uuid.uuid4())' (25 characters to 17).

What problem is uuidutils.generate_uuid() actually solving?

Also, assuming this patch is necessary, shouldn't this patch convert all of the direct uses of uuid.uuid4() too?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-11-13 19:50:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

reasoning for it can be found here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15737/

I think the fact there are uuid4 references outside of this is a bug and should be fixed separately.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-13 19:51:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I had the same reaction when this was submitted to oslo:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15737/

Waldon pointed out that it at least standardized on uuid.uuid4(), as opposed to another UUID.  It wasn't that big of a deal, so I just let it go.  That doesn't mean we have to let it in to nova, though.  

I agree that it really doesn't seem to add much value..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 19:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-merge/11974 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-docs/7707 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/13017 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-python26/9158 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-python27/9227 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/18341 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16005/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/2856 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-13 20:04:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I haven't seen the problems explained in that bug.

Do we have examples where it wasn't converted to a string? Isn't this really a sign of insufficient testing instead?

Do we have examples where uuid4 wasn't used? Does it even matter as long as it's still unique? AFAICT, all of the uuid module functions generate strings with dashes.

Obviously the code has been inconsistent in the past about using utils.gen_uuid() vs uuid.uuid4(), but what is going to enforce using uuidutils.generate_uuid()?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-13 22:07:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-21 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-21 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Specify URL for swift backend

fixes bug #1037708

Originally the swift backend hardwired the publicURL. This patch
allows the user to specify a URL.

Change-Id: I9de5f593f3783fe5c85b90258818279b24bc66f1
DocImpact

commit_message:
Check functions before using them.

Add in checks to ensure that a method that is being called
is not private and that it actually implements a '__call__'
action thus signifying it is a callable object.

Change-Id: I8be9ba69a28590db4a35a32df24fabe7a4bf16bc

I would never dare to -1 a patch submitted by our glorious PTL, but since Jenkins already did, I feel authorised to do that!

Minor nits inline.

Also, I was wandering whether we need to change _get_router_for_internal_subnet before relaxing the check on external networks. 
in order to support multiple floating IPs from different ext nets mapped to the same internal IP I think we'll need to have multiple routers on a given subnet. At a first glance that routine would not return the appropriate router_id in this case."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

Salvatore, yes, I actually thought a bit about that myself while doing the patch, but then decided to be a bit more conservative since this was targeting a backport.

To confirm that we're talking about the same think, I think you'd want to change two things about _get_router_for_internal_subnet() 

1) search for all router-interface ports on that network, and confirm that one exists with an IP address on the requested subnet.  

2) confirm that the corresponding router (identified by device_id on the port) has an external_gateway to the right external network.  This is not currently checked."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
bug 1057844: improve floating-ip association checks

allow multiple floating ips to be associated with the same internal port
as long as they map to different external nets (not yet supported in
Folsom) or different internal fixed IPs.  With Quantum, there is no
need to disallow either scenario.

Also improve check for a valid external network to router to internal
subnet path when a floating IP is bound.

Change-Id: Iced675e1f064172ee8a5bb6b9e37032e83af5711

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

I might be wrong but I think there are several misunderstandings here.
The goal of the patch is to ensure openstack.common logging works fine, and this is not happening at the moment as we do not have project_id in our context. Probably Mark refers to 'configuration' problem as the log output template can be specified in the configuration file; but probably user_id and project_id are hardcoded and cannot be controlled (this I don't know, to be honest)

Hence I might argue that the fix for this bug would probably limit to ensuring loggin works as expected. Frankly from your comments I could not find a argument which justifies the use of a different RPC context for fixing the log issue. Can you elaborate a little bit more?

Mark's comment about DB access, as I read it, is more about the fact that quantum.context has a session method which can potentially give you access to the quantum database. I tend to agree to the fact that we do not want to give agent developers a leeway for gaining direct access to Quantum database.

You also have a comment about a flaw in fake RPC context which is created. are you referring to the the 'augment_rpc_context' function which you removed in this patch?"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The bug looks like more like a configuration problem.  I also don't like the fact that this change converts agents to use context that provides attributes to access the database.  We've been working towards removing direct db access."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

markmcclain,
Not all the message processing functions can do via simple API calling. To access DB in these functions is normal. It does not hurt since message queue is in data network, which normal tenant don't have to. 

In addition, TO scatter augument_context way everywhere is not a good idea.

use a random rpc context with a fake tenant and user is not a good way too.

hope y can think about it again.

Thanks
Yong Sheng Gong"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Another problem is that openstack-common does that in a default way, I think we need to comply with it. other wise it lose its existing meaning.

It is not a configuration problem, quantum should be able to run with default options value as possible as it can.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Helo, salv:
The common log is obviously from nova, whose context has user_id and project_id, instead of user and tenant in our context.

nova's RPC call proxy will use nova context which has user_id and project_id. So to fix this problem, our RPC context should be like such too.

If the agents need to access the db, the session object in the quantum context cannot work alone. The engine must be initiated as well. To remove your concerns, I can restore the dispatcher back to original one on the agent side.

our agents or plugins are using a random quantum context:
self.rpc_context = context.RequestContext('quantum', 'quantum',		        self.rpc_context = context.get_admin_context()
	                                                  is_admin=False)
to send out RPC message. and then on the receiver side, we augment it into admin quantum context. (in the case of plugin)
This patch refactors the codes and make then clean. (by removing the augment_rpc_context)

Thanks
Yong Sheng Gong"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15726/3/check/gate-quantum-merge/2539 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/15726/3/check/gate-quantum-pep8/2398 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15726/3/check/gate-quantum-python26/2168 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15726/3/check/gate-quantum-python27/2169 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

(4 inline comments)

I understand what you're doing with removing augment_context on the server side. I don't see any problem with that. I was just slightly suprised as it came a bit unexpected in a patch whose aim was apparently different.
But as you said, it's a refactoring activity which I do not find harmful, so I am happy with it.

I'd like to hear from Mark as well, but I think we should leave the agents using standard rpc context.

I am reviewing with -1 as there is a typo in a file name which needs to be addressed."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for your replies.
I will wait for the patch with the fixed unit test name to remove -1. 
In the meanwhile I will try and find some time to do some tests regarding agent-side ctx, see comment inline.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-11-21 05:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (4 inline comments)

How about to use a quantum context without session?

commit_message:
Fix context problem

On plugin side, we use normal API context if any to call RPC methods.
We use our plugin dispatcher to convert RPC context into quantum admin
context. After that the callback's functions have the first argument context
as normal quantum context.

On agent side, we use admin context without session property as its
RPC calling context. Call back context is default RPCCommonContext in
Openstack common modules.

This patch also fixes the problem in the following bug:

Bug #1077012

Change-Id: I913b48dcd84d275cd7de30ca990be00c243e63ea

commit_message:
Rename sql_pool_size to sql_max_pool_size

A recent patch adds a sql_pool_size config option.  This renames it to
sql_max_pool_size and sets a default that equals SQLAlchemy's default
(5).

eventlet's db_pool allows setting a minimum size, so this is to prep for
adding a sql_min_pool_size option.  Should remove some confusion.

No need to support sql_pool_size for backwards compatibility as it
was to be a new option in Grizzly, anyway.

Also fixes the previous patch to not set pool options if using
StaticPool or NullPool.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic41d138a1ee4cdaf785e45091bd5668045153b90
