commit_message:
use deleted=False instead of deleted=0 in queries

Mysql treats 0 and False as the same thing, but this isn't true for
postgresql which is much more strongly typed. Our whitebox testing
was failing on postgresql because of this assumption.

Change-Id: I1a7339814b1de6e0c5874ba5b56fc90db6fbb012

commit_message:
make it possible to run only one test in tempest

we were always adding 'tempest' to the list for tests in
run_tests.sh, which didn't let you use the wrapper for running
a single tempest test. This change should fix that.

Probably could be cleaner, but my bash-fu is weaksause.

Change-Id: I5a3600b14214dd38be505481dad5ab72998df386

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Aaron, Nachi,
I think we are discussing how security group should work. It should be documented somewhere. I will create a wiki page on OpenStack wiki and then let's continue the specification. I believe it is very helpful for security group implementers and reviewing nachi's security group implementation for linuxbridge.

About this patch, we seem to have reached the consensus on outbound traffic, so this patch can be merged IMO.

if it is ok, i will approve this patch."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks Aaron, that's what I expected. I think Nachi's proposed definition needs to be modified, but I could not figure out what cases Nachi is taking care of."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Let me clarify the expected behavior of security group.

In my understanding, the expected behavior before this patch is:

- 'ingress' means inbound traffic to a VM and 'egress' means outbounnd
traffic from a VM (it is same definition as Amazon VPC).

-  Only traffic matchecd with security group rules are allowed.
  Thus when there is no rule defined, all traffic are dropped.
  (This concept applies to both ingress and egress traffic)

This patch is changing the expected behavior of the security group
implementation (e.g., your NVP plugin or nachi's iptables driver).
Is that right?

Now, the implementation is expected to work as follows:

- (For ingress) Only traffic matchecd with security group rules are allowed.
  When there is no rule defined, all traffic are dropped.

- (For egress) If there is no rules, all traffic are allowed.
  Otherwise only traffic matchecd with security group rules are allowed
  and traffic not matched are dropped.

If my understading above is right, your patch looks good to me.

(My opinion is neutral. Both behavior before and after this patch are reasonable for me. Note that we need to document it for plugin implementors.)"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Nachi, Aaron,

Let me clarify the detail.

Assuming a case where VM1 belongs to "default" security group, VM2 belongs to "sg1" security group and both security groups have no rules, should traffic from VM1 to VM2 be allowed? According to Nachi's definition, this case matches "When there is no rule defined, *traffic from non-member of default security groups* are dropped."'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I talked with nachi. He wanted to mention about the behavior of the default security group and the general behavior I wrote in the previous comment seems OK. I will approve this patch.

I created a Wiki page http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum/SecurityGroups to document and discuss the quantum security groups spec. I hope this will help you.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score; No score

This patch has a denpendency on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15074/, but it seems not to depend on it. I will upload the rebased version soon. It is better to be merged before testing nachi's secgroup linuxbridge support."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

HI Akihiro, Aaron

IMO default should be this.

- (For ingress) Only traffic matched with security group rules are allowed.
  When there is no rule defined, *traffic from non-member of default security groups* are dropped.
- (For egress) If there is no rules, all traffic are allowed.
  Otherwise only traffic matchecd with security group rules are allowed
  and traffic not matched are dropped.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Akihiro, yup that is correct. I made this change so that we could be exactly inline with http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_SecurityGroups.html since that's probably what most people are used to."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Nachi, Yes, correct.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

No, VM1 and VM2 should not be able to communicate in that case.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-11-19 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
All egress traffic allowed by default should be implied

This commit removes the egress rules that were created by default
to align with the way security groups work in amazon VPC.
"By default, all egress is allowed from the security
group until you add outbound rules to the group (then only the egress you
specified is allowed)."

Change-Id: I63936fbf76ea9a2828c8923be6ec14aac46b21bd

Handle nova.flags removal

nova.flags has been removed and we're now supposed to use nova.config
Put some compat code for Foslom.

Change-Id: I53bd74310df35ba37fdaaf26139ab73a46bebd1f
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'created': '2012-11-13 20:50:07.000000000', 'message': "Fix lazy-listing of object segments.

When responding to a GET request for a manifest, it was intended that
the proxy server lazily fetch the pieces of the container
listing. That way, a single client request doesn't immediately turn
into a bunch of requests to backends. The additional requests should
only get made if the client is putting in the work of receiving the
object body.

However, commit 156f27c accidentally changed this so that all the
pieces of the container listing are eagerly fetched up-front. Better
yet, if an object has more than CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT (default
10,000) segments, the container listing is then fetched a second time,
albeit lazily, while streaming out the response.

This commit restores the laziness and adds tests for it.

Change-Id: I49840a7059e6f999ce19199ecb10cdb77358526b

commit_message:
Fix lazy-listing of object segments.

When responding to a GET request for a manifest, it was intended that
the proxy server lazily fetch the pieces of the container
listing. That way, a single client request doesn't immediately turn
into a bunch of requests to backends. The additional requests should
only get made if the client is putting in the work of receiving the
object body.

However, commit 156f27c accidentally changed this so that all the
pieces of the container listing are eagerly fetched up-front. Better
yet, if an object has more than CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT (default
10,000) segments, the container listing is then fetched a second time,
albeit lazily, while streaming out the response.

This commit restores the laziness and adds tests for it.

Change-Id: I49840a7059e6f999ce19199ecb10cdb77358526b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 23:59:55.000000000', 'message': "Stop logging all registry client exceptions

Not all exceptions need to be logged as ERROR in the glance-api
log when - for instance, a user asking for an image that does not
exist doesn't mean an ERROR actually occurred. This logs the exception
name at INFO level and allows an operator to get the traceback details
when running at DEBUG level. An ERROR won't be logged at all, even in
the case of a 500-level response from glance-registry. An operator
would be alerted with an ERROR log in the glance-registry log in that
case.

Fixes bug 1079211.

Change-Id: Ie2bba3105f8d9f3de97bc50132fb046baf710a90
"}, {'created': '2012-11-17 00:01:42.000000000', 'message': "Stop logging all registry client exceptions

Not all exceptions need to be logged as ERROR in the glance-api
log when - for instance, a user asking for an image that does not
exist doesn't mean an ERROR actually occurred. This logs the exception
name at INFO level. An ERROR won't be logged at all, even in
the case of a 500-level response from glance-registry. An operator
would be alerted with an ERROR log in the glance-registry log in that
case.

Fixes bug 1079211.

Change-Id: Ie2bba3105f8d9f3de97bc50132fb046baf710a90
"}]
commit_message:
Stop logging all registry client exceptions

Not all exceptions need to be logged as ERROR in the glance-api
log when - for instance, a user asking for an image that does not
exist doesn't mean an ERROR actually occurred. This logs the exception
name at INFO level. An ERROR won't be logged at all, even in
the case of a 500-level response from glance-registry. An operator
would be alerted with an ERROR log in the glance-registry log in that
case.

Fixes bug 1079211.

Change-Id: Ie2bba3105f8d9f3de97bc50132fb046baf710a90

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-11-16 02:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris:

Why in the world did you break this simple concept into multiple patches. It seems like a single logical idea: just remove flags. Why not keep it as a single patch?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-11-16 02:36:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Keep people on their toes.  Mostly just because it touched so many files.  Maybe it was better to squash it all!'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-11-16 02:53:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Comstud: I -2'd the remaining split up branches. I feel like this sort of thing sets a bad precedent... when to break things up and when not to. Perhaps we can have a single final changeset that completes the operation?

I don't care who does that..."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-11-16 02:57:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's fine.  I think you're commenting in the review which does what you ask :)"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-16 16:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Personally, I prefer small changes like removing "from nova import flags" be split up into smaller chunks; I feel that it makes it easier to browse through the changes.  Part of that feeling is also driven by the way I review patches; I start at the beginning and hit the next file link, but whatever Javascript Gerrit is using gets slower and slower the deeper in I get.  I also know people who prefer opening all the diffs in browser tabs, which obviously becomes a problem for patches that hit lots of files.  Finally, I feel that having patches that hit smaller number of files makes it more likely that a reviewer will review that patch.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-11-16 18:15:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin: In general I agree with you. Smaller patches are better. I don't think that is a hard line rule and in this case there really is very little substance... it is simply removing flags import statements.

To me a patchset is a logical sequence of how a developer thinks about (and implements) a feature/fix/etc. In the case of this patch 'Remove nova.flags' I personally would write a script, use a sed statement, and rip it out in a single action. Nothing else too it! IMO splitting it up is pretty much work for nothing. Not the mention the hours of CI resources and general upstream thrashing it causes.

If I understand you correctly the main cause of your concern is more of a Gerrit limitation... which makes it hard to do reviews which touch lots of files? When I review this commit like this one I simply pull it locally and diff the changes in a terminal window. Makes it really quick and easy to see that the flags were ripped out correctly. Right tool for the right job I guess?

The only good reason to split this out I can think of would be to help avoid conflicts in Nova... but I'm not sure that is going to be a problem since it is very straightforward. Once it gets rebased it will just go right in. *And* like I mention above any problem this solves is somewhat negated by the extra CI resources, review time, rekicks, etc required to get the longer patch series in anyway.

Just my take. Perhaps others disagree."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-16 18:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think you hit the nail on the head Dan about when it makes sense to split patches up and when it doesn't

In the case of s/FLAGS/CONF/ I did it as a handful of separate patches because one single patch would likely have to be rebased over and over, whereas some of the individual patches got merged with no rebases. In the case of this change, there's going to be far less conflicts

As for reviewing a large patch modifying loads of files in the web UI, use the "gitweb" link above to get to the "commitdiff" - https://review.openstack.org/gitweb?p=openstack%2Fnova.git;a=commitdiff;h=3fdba4b16f47974ab7ed7735f6c9f5bfe43caeab'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-17 15:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-17 15:45:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, I meant to mention - I hadn't actually seen Chris's series ending in  Iafb81b717b16f706f017b4e8c4c045f41d6e4163 before proposing this patch"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-17 16:03:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Remove nova.flags

Now that options have all moved from nova.flags to nova.config, we can
safely remove the nova.flags imports and replace them with nova.config
imports.

Change-Id: Ic077a72dd6419bbf1e1babe71acfa43c4e8b55c8

subject: Remove FLAGS
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I hit the rest of these in one of my reviews as well.... except the actual removal of FLAGS of course.  As I mentioned in the comment in that one review of mine... I'm a little worried about things not shipped with nova and their use of nova.flags and nova.flags.FLAGS.  It seems like we need to mark it deprecated in some way and remove after G.  Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:45:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, I'll repeat what I said in the other review:

  We make no guarantees about internal APIs - anyone with an external extension has to be prepared to re-work stuff when they re-base

  Trying to support backwards compat for stuff like this just uneccesarily hamstrings us

... and say it a bit more strongly this time ...

It's utter lunacy to make any backwards compat commitments for internal stuff like this

And it's pretty useless to anyone in any case - we'll never get to a stage where external extensions won't need updating to work with newer versions of the code, so why pick one particular internal API to make a commitment

External API authors just need to suck it up when they rebase to a new version, and they already know that"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:47:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh, and if it looked like I intended to keep this around for backwards compat when I did the CONF->FLAGS patches ... that wasn't the case

I left nova.flags there so that I could split up the CONF->FLAGS changes into independent patches to make merging them easier ... I always intended to come back and kill off nova.flags when they were all merged"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:47:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Didn't see the other review comment yet.  Anyway, that all makes sense.  I was just double-checking.  I'm trying to be rather conscious of backwards-compatible changes."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:49:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sure, thanks Chris

I'm conscious of backwards compat when it comes to things like config options, the REST APIs, the RPC APIs, etc. ... but want to avoid us locking down stuff that doesn't need to be"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:49:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Got it.  Sorry, I got tired of seeing the unused import flagged from pyflakes every time I opened a file. :)  Figured I'd help take care of it.  Agree with moving the shared options into a method like Johannes said."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-16 01:15:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

commit_message:
Remove nova.flags usage

The only one left is now in libvirt for the compute driver. How to remove
this and rewrite this pollster is still under discussion.

This implements blueprint nova-flags-removal.

Change-Id: Ife54e402cb307b9b4cb360d8ee54683ac1e73e1c
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-18 21:04:40.000000000', 'message': "Set node_availability_zone in XenAPIAggregateTestCase

In XenAPIAggregateTestCase some service records
are directly injected to the db for testing with customized AZ
values . The AZ doesn't match the default availability
zone setting (nova), and may or may not be overwritten during
heart beat message update. It is mostly ignored but
sometimes make the test_remove_host_from_aggregate_error()
test fail, as discovered in the servicegroup test.
Set the AZ explicitly to get rid of the non-determinism.

Change-Id: I2ded5314480b2b7eb2254a58e3eb7ca9e3f8b32d
"}]
commit_message:
Set node_availability_zone in XenAPIAggregateTestCase

In XenAPIAggregateTestCase some service records
are directly injected to the db for testing with customized AZ
values . The AZ doesn't match the default availability
zone setting (nova), and may or may not be overwritten during
heart beat message update. It is mostly ignored but
sometimes make the test_remove_host_from_aggregate_error()
test fail, as discovered in the servicegroup test.
Set the AZ explicitly to get rid of the non-determinism.

Change-Id: I2ded5314480b2b7eb2254a58e3eb7ca9e3f8b32d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-17 01:28:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove IP-based container-sync ACLs from auth middlewares.

The determination of the client IP looked at the X-Cluster-Client-Ip
and X-Forwarded-For headers in the incoming HTTP request. This is
trivially spoofable by a malicious client, so there's no security
gained by having the check there.

Worse, having the check there provides a false sense of security to
cluster operators. It sounds like it's based on the client IP, so an
attacker would have to do IP spoofing to defeat it. However, it's
really just a shared secret, and there's already a secret key set
up. Basically, it looks like 2-factor auth (IP+key), but it's really
1-factor (key).

Now, the one case where this might provide some security is where the
Swift cluster is behind an external load balancer that strips off the
X-Cluster-Client-Ip and X-Forwarded-For headers and substitutes its
own. I don't think it's worth the tradeoff, hence this commit.

Fixes bug 1068420 for very small values of "fixes".

Change-Id: I2bef64c2e1e4df8a612a5531a35721202deb6964
'}, {'created': '2012-11-17 02:48:48.000000000', 'message': 'Remove IP-based container-sync ACLs from auth middlewares.

The determination of the client IP looked at the X-Cluster-Client-Ip
and X-Forwarded-For headers in the incoming HTTP request. This is

Worse, having the check there provides a false sense of security to
cluster operators. It sounds like it's based on the client IP, so an
attacker would have to do IP spoofing to defeat it. However, it's
really just a shared secret, and there's already a secret key set
up. Basically, it looks like 2-factor auth (IP+key), but it's really
1-factor (key).

Now, the one case where this might provide some security is where the
Swift cluster is behind an external load balancer that strips off the
X-Cluster-Client-Ip and X-Forwarded-For headers and substitutes its
own. I don't think it's worth the tradeoff, hence this commit.

Fixes bug 1068420 for very small values of "fixes".

DocImpact

Change-Id: I2bef64c2e1e4df8a612a5531a35721202deb6964
'}]
commit_message:
Remove IP-based container-sync ACLs from auth middlewares.

The determination of the client IP looked at the X-Cluster-Client-Ip
and X-Forwarded-For headers in the incoming HTTP request. This is
trivially spoofable by a malicious client, so there's no security
gained by having the check there.

Worse, having the check there provides a false sense of security to
cluster operators. It sounds like it's based on the client IP, so an
attacker would have to do IP spoofing to defeat it. However, it's
really just a shared secret, and there's already a secret key set
up. Basically, it looks like 2-factor auth (IP+key), but it's really
1-factor (key).

Now, the one case where this might provide some security is where the
Swift cluster is behind an external load balancer that strips off the
X-Cluster-Client-Ip and X-Forwarded-For headers and substitutes its
own. I don't think it's worth the tradeoff, hence this commit.

Fixes bug 1068420 for very small values of "fixes".

DocImpact

Change-Id: I2bef64c2e1e4df8a612a5531a35721202deb6964

commit_message:
add instance_type_extra_specs to instances

Adding instance_type_extra_specs as instance['extra_specs']
so that this info is passed to driver.spawn() later on.
This is needed by the baremetal driver.

Change-Id: Icbfba835c9a060193597cc00a7c0e404b7ccfdd4

commit_message:
update api_samples add os-services module

part of blueprint:apis-for-nova-manage

os-services is a new module for to support getting
rid of nova-manage. Add this to the all_extensions
api listing.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I3a954de59b16fd86d81204a535f8b152f3073468

whoops, did not see that this was for stable/folsom. 

you should not post something to stable/folsom until AFTER it has been merged into master.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-18 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I noticed that the patch for master branch is already merged. Please ignore my previous comment.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-18 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(As Dan already says, this patch is proposed to stable/folsom directly, so it must not be merged.)

The following is a suggestion for this patch. I am happy you would consider it when your propose the patch to master.

Quota extension does not depend on plugin implementation. I do not prefer to adding an entry plugin by plugin for such extension. Is it better to introduce "ALL" (which matches all core plugins)? Otherwise I think it is better to add quota extension support for all plugins other than OVS and LB in a single patch.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-18 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I clear -1 for it.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-18 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Change looks kosher. Unable to test.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-18 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

I have taken Alex's suggestion and provided a get_collection_query(), which then can be called as needed by normal getters, or specialized count getters. Also, the count getters don't use the "fields" argument anymore, as Alex had pointed out that this is not really needed there.

Some comments have been simplified.

The _my_get_networks() function has been removed. The plugin relies on the base plugin's implementation of the resource count method.'}, {'account_id': 6139, 'date': '2012-11-17 19:57:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Zhongyue, originally I had a count_only parameter (for some internal functions), similar to what you suggested. However, the review feedback on that was that a function shouldn't get a different return type, just because a parameter value changes. Personally, I actually don't mind the changed return type, but review consensus seemed to be that changing return types are to be frowned upon.

As for the changed return type and optional parameter in the top-level function (such as get_networks()): That actually makes it more difficult to call an optimized count version in the quota functions. The idea is that not all plugins have the optimized count capabilities. Therefore, the caller would have to try with the count_only attribute, possibly get an exception and then retry. On the other hand, the presence of a specialised 'count' getter can easily be tested for with hasattr(), thus avoiding the need to throw exceptions."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-17 19:57:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Use DB count method to retrieve resource counts. Fixes bug 1075369.

During quota check we used to simply retrieve the entire collection
of resources from the database, then counting them in Python. This
patch introduces an additional flag to the _get_collection() method,
which indicates whether only the count is needed and then uses the
count method of the DB.

In order to take advantage of this, plugins can now implement
get_*_count() methods for their resources. This is used (if present)
by the quota checking function.

commit_message:
Use DB count to get resource counts.

Fixes bug 1075369.

During quota check we used to simply retrieve the entire collection
of resources from the database, then counting them in Python. This
patch introduces a specialized _get_collection_count() method, which
instead take advantage of the DB's built-in count capabilities.

In order to take advantage of this, plugins can now implement
get_*_count() methods for their resources. This is used (if present)
by the quota checking function.

Patch incorporates review feedback from Dan W, Alex Xu, Zhongyue Luo,
Edgar Magana, Akihiro Motoki and gongysh.

Change-Id: I87e2d0294e116e8147fed2ee90c9eb0cf1a54362

Quite a few things on this one:

1) This fails miserably when there is no element "vnc_console" with a JavaScript error.

2) This is VERY specific to the vnc_console page and thusly should not be in this location as this runs on every page load.

3) We use jQuery for DOM related event attaching, and node lookup.

4) We never, ever want to wholesale overwrite the window.onload event handler, if you want to attach JS to the window loading, do so within the Horizon JS namespace using the provided function: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/horizon/static/horizon/js/horizon.js#L17

5) We find it to be generally bad practice to steal focus from where the use last had it.

6) The Selenium tests fail, due to point #1'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-17 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It fixes the bug, but what's the cost?

This removes the ability for eventlet to switch threads at some key places - namely read and write.  That's a bit concerning to me ..."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-08 23:10:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-11-09 08:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

yeah if this is just a "fix" for auth_token middleware, let's see if just changing in c-api is good enough?

but like... I'm still confused?  Monkey-patching os isn't going to change the errno?

When I look at auth_token i see it check if the file exists, then download it in place... how is this not a race?  Won't a concurrent call read a half written cert but then raise immediately because the file *exists*?

https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/middleware/auth_token.py#L735

Did we try updating fetch_signing_cert to download into temp and move into place?  Or make cert_file_missing synchronize?  

I guess I need to try harder to duplicate this, I only ever saw the failures in the gates, and I don't understand why this only effects cinder... unless I guess the other api servers don't green os and so not yielding on the popen calls avoids the race?

I'm just confused... as usual.  sorry :('}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-11-09 09:25:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

oh, this helps :D

https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/pull-request/24/fix-waitpid-returning-0-0-and-add-test/diff

so there's a bug there, but it kinda makes you wonder how it works at all?  Does it only manifest itself where there's a pipeline/multiple children?"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-11-09 09:55:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lolwut?!

import eventlet
eventlet.monkey_patch(all=True)

import subprocess

process = subprocess.Popen(['false'])
process.wait()
assert process.returncode == 1

How can this *not* work!?  Please merge this."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-11-09 15:55:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

from eventlet.green import subprocess

^ werx

YAY THE WORLD MAKES SENSE!

The green subclass of Popen is a totally different impl using self.poll() which is already non-blocking in stdlib.


cinder bins should monkey-patch keystone.common.cms.Popen the same was the keystone-all bin does in monkeypatch_cms, yes?

Maybe it's still a good idea to abandon "green" os since we know os.wait and os.waitpid are broken...  I can't think of anywhere we os.fdopen???

but wait, why is it not reasonable for auth_token to try: from eventlet.green import subprocess; except ImportError import subprocess ?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-09 21:10:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

unfortunately abandoning os means we also lose os.read and os.write which are used when reading and writing from fds. There is discussion about using green.subprocess in auth_token on the ml. The problem is that it needs to be able to run under apache etc. where eventlet should not be used.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-09 22:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

here is a workaround on the keystone side:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15791/1'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-17 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-07 21:50:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix 401 from auth_token middleware

The openssl popen call to verify the token returns an error code
of 2 when a file doesn't exist. Normally this is caught and the
relevant file is downloaded, but monkeypatching os causes this
error code to be eaten and cinder to return a 401. Note that this
is likely a race condition that depends on exactly when greenthreads
are switching that is causing the return code from Popen to get
overwritten.

It is possible that this is exposing an underlying bug in eventlet
but the workaround is simply to make sure that we don't monkeypatch
os.

Fixes bug 1075838

Change-Id: I69ba75136e32e95c6fdf108f0c4fe21a5e3bdbe6
(cherry picked from commit 4e619fbef8671697bfec8e752818944c9f96cd72)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 401 from auth_token middleware

The openssl popen call to verify the token returns an error code
of 2 when a file doesn't exist. Normally this is caught and the
relevant file is downloaded, but monkeypatching os causes this
error code to be eaten and cinder to return a 401. Note that this
is likely a race condition that depends on exactly when greenthreads
are switching that is causing the return code from Popen to get
overwritten.

It is possible that this is exposing an underlying bug in eventlet
but the workaround is simply to make sure that we don't monkeypatch
os.

Fixes bug 1075838

Change-Id: I69ba75136e32e95c6fdf108f0c4fe21a5e3bdbe6
(cherry picked from commit 4e619fbef8671697bfec8e752818944c9f96cd72)

[{'created': '2012-10-22 18:05:49.000000000', 'message': 'Run unittests with testr.

Add testr dependencies to tools/test-requires. Add a testr.conf to tell
testr how to run the tests. Modify tox to run testr instead of nosetests
when running the python unittests.

Did not remove nose and its dependencies from the tools/test-requires
file as the coverage job has not been converted to testr.

This is a proof of concept more than anything else. There are several
issues that will probably need to be corrected with test output before
we can use this regularly.
1. Test stdout is printed which is more noise than we are used to.
2. Need a way to convert test results to html for easy consumption.

Change-Id: I573199e0722ef80a5e349f053501c0cdeb522fb0

commit_message:
Run unittests with testr.

Add testr dependencies to tools/test-requires. Add a testr.conf to tell
testr how to run the tests. Modify tox to run testr instead of nosetests
when running the python unittests.

Continue to use nose to collect test coverage. Not all of nose's
dependencies are necessary to collect coverage. Those that are not
necessary have been removed.

Making all of this work required moving the unittests to testtools
instead of unittest2. This required some minor test changes (some of
which should probably be made regardless of unittest platform).

This is a proof of concept more than anything else. There are several
issues that will probably need to be corrected with test output before
we can use this regularly.
1. Test stdout is added as subunit details per test. This output can be
   found in .testrepository/$TEST_RUN_NUMBER and more conveniently
   ./testr_subunit_log. If you want the test stdout to pass through to
   your terminal set the OS_STDOUT_NOCAPTURE environment variable to
   True.
2. Need to report test results in various ways. Realtime result output
   and a human readable log format (html or txt) are needed.
3. Using nose for coverage collection is probably not a good long term
   solution (adds extra dependencies and is something different that
   needs maintenance). Need a better testr supported solution.

Note tests.test_http:test_get has been modified to fail. This has been
done to demontrate what testr's failure output looks like.

Change-Id: I573199e0722ef80a5e349f053501c0cdeb522fb0

commit_message:
Unpin keystoneclient dependency

The new 0.2.0 keystoneclient was released with no api changes, and
glanceclients dependency breaks gating so unpin it.

Change-Id: I9cbe2ebb462005ebfea3b7a0e68ca39069a0765f

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-10-23 18:00:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This seems to break existing functionality. For example, using a ':' in a header now gets escaped. This breaks auth requests to clusters using tempauth and swauth."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-10-23 19:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

John,

nice catch. Assuming that the allowed separators for HTTP headers according to RFC-2616 are '()<>@,;:\\"/[]?={} \t', his will not escape unwanted symbols:

    allowed_separators = '()<>@,;:\\"/[]?={} \t'

    def putheader_escaped(key, value):
        func(quote(key, allowed_separators),
             quote(value, allowed_separators))

and will probably work as expected. Any thoughts on that?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-10-23 19:58:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ya, that seems to work'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-10-24 09:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-24 09:16:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Force utf-8 encode of HTTPConnection params

This patch forces swiftclient to encode to utf-8
all url and headers arguments, to avoid the
UnicodeDecodeError which is raised by '\r\n'.join([])
invoked in htplib.py.

Currently the affected projects are Horizon(upload file
with unicode name) and swiftclient CLI('swift post' with
unicode filename as header)

This is also a follow-up of this review:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14216/

I'd still want to hear what the Swift core devs
think of it. Is it better to create a new
AutoEncodingHTTPConnection? Or to handle the connection
creation and make sure there are no unicode and utf-8
string at the same time. If these unicode checks have to
be added in the calling code(Dashboard, CLI), there are
so many places to be added, and also in all new commands
that might be exposed from the API.

Fixes bug 1008940

Change-Id: Ice2aa29024429d3e6f569a88d5cf8b4202537827

The new put_metadata() does that for the client now (for POSTs and DELETEs), but the one case of handling PUT must explicitly call mkstemp() before it finally calls put().

If you feel that the assert is not necessary, we can pull it, since if one does not call mkstemp() before put() we'll just get a problem with the renamer() code handling a None object for the initial name."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-11-16 22:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 13:59:05.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor DiskFile to hide temp file names and exts

This set of changes reworks the DiskFile class to remove the "extension"
parameter from the put() method, offering the new put_metadata() method with
an optional tombstone keyword boolean, and changes the mkstemp method to only
return the file descriptor.

Reviewing the code it was found that the temporary file name created as a
result of calling DiskFile.mkstemp() was never used by the caller, but the
caller was responsible for passing it back to the DiskFile.put() method. That
seems like too much information is exposed to the caller, when all the caller
requires is the file descriptor to write data into it.

Upon further review, the mkstemp() method was used in three places: PUT, POST
and DELETE method handling. Of those three cases, only PUT requires the file
descriptor, since it is responsible for writing the object contents. For POST
and DELETE, DiskFile only needs to associate metadata with the correct file
name. We abstract the pattern that those two use (once we also refactor the
code to move the fetch of the delete-at metadata, and subsequent
delete-at-update initiation, from under the mkstemp context) by adding the new
put_metadata() method.

As a result, the DiskFile class is then free to do whatever file system
operations it must to meet the API, without the caller having to know more
than just how to write data to a file descriptor. Note that DiskFile itself
key'd off of the '.ts' and '.meta' extensions for its operations, and for that
to work properly, the caller had to know to use those correctly. With this
change, the caller has no knowledge of how the file system is being used to
accomplish data and metadata storage.

See also Question 213796 at:
    https://answers.launchpad.net/swift/+question/213796

Change-Id: I267f68e64391ba627b2a13682393bec62600159d
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor DiskFile to hide temp file names and exts

This set of changes reworks the DiskFile class to remove the "extension"
parameter from the put() method, offering the new put_metadata() method with
an optional tombstone keyword boolean, and changes the mkstemp method to only
return the file descriptor.

Reviewing the code it was found that the temporary file name created as a
result of calling DiskFile.mkstemp() was never used by the caller, but the
caller was responsible for passing it back to the DiskFile.put() method. That
seems like too much information is exposed to the caller, when all the caller
requires is the file descriptor to write data into it.

Upon further review, the mkstemp() method was used in three places: PUT, POST
and DELETE method handling. Of those three cases, only PUT requires the file
descriptor, since it is responsible for writing the object contents. For POST
and DELETE, DiskFile only needs to associate metadata with the correct file
name. We abstract the pattern that those two use (once we also refactor the
code to move the fetch of the delete-at metadata, and subsequent
delete-at-update initiation, from under the mkstemp context) by adding the new
put_metadata() method.

As a result, the DiskFile class is then free to do whatever file system
operations it must to meet the API, without the caller having to know more
than just how to write data to a file descriptor. Note that DiskFile itself
key'd off of the '.ts' and '.meta' extensions for its operations, and for that
to work properly, the caller had to know to use those correctly. With this
change, the caller has no knowledge of how the file system is being used to
accomplish data and metadata storage.

See also Question 213796 at:
    https://answers.launchpad.net/swift/+question/213796

Change-Id: I267f68e64391ba627b2a13682393bec62600159d
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make assertion failures more informative.

The assertIn, assertEquals and other assertions will output more information
than assertTrue, which outputs:
False is not True
on failure.

Change-Id: Ibbf90a479174d16cac5361519643b55744678a84

Okay. The code's a lot less intrusive than I thought it would be, it comes with tests, and it doesn't break anything for me.

I still think it's a good idea to keep all your servers' times in sync, but this does help if your cluster's time and your caches' times drift a little.

There's a couple little nitpicks in inline comments, but nothing worth holding up the commit over. revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 05:23:42.000000000', 'message': "Use a delta timeout for memcache where possible

We use a delta timeout value for timeouts under 30 days (in seconds)
since that is the limit which the memcached ascii protocol will
recognize a timeout as a delta. Greater than 30 days and it interprets
it as an absolute time in seconds since the epoch.

This helps to address an often difficult-to-debug problem of time
drift between memcache clients and the memcache servers. Prior to this
change, if a client's time drifts behind the servers, short timeouts
run the danger of not being cached at all. If a client's time drifts
ahead of the servers, short timeouts run the danger of persisting too
long. Using delta's avoids this affect. For absolute timeouts 30 days
or more in the future small time drifts between clients and servers
are inconsequential.

See also bug 1076148 (https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1076148).

This also fixes incr and decr to handle timeout values in the same way
timeouts are handled for set operations.

Change-Id: Ie36dbcedfe9b4db9f77ed4ea9b70ff86c5773310
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2012-11-16 19:58:57.000000000', 'message': "Use a delta timeout for memcache where possible

We use a delta timeout value for timeouts under 30 days (in seconds)
since that is the limit which the memcached protocols will recognize a
timeout as a delta. Greater than 30 days and it interprets it as an
absolute time in seconds since the epoch.

This helps to address an often difficult-to-debug problem of time
drift between memcache clients and the memcache servers. Prior to this
change, if a client's time drifts behind the servers, short timeouts
run the danger of not being cached at all. If a client's time drifts
ahead of the servers, short timeouts run the danger of persisting too
long. Using delta's avoids this affect. For absolute timeouts 30 days
or more in the future small time drifts between clients and servers
are inconsequential.

See also bug 1076148 (https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1076148).

This also fixes incr and decr to handle timeout values in the same way
timeouts are handled for set operations.

Change-Id: Ie36dbcedfe9b4db9f77ed4ea9b70ff86c5773310
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Use a delta timeout for memcache where possible

We use a delta timeout value for timeouts under 30 days (in seconds)
since that is the limit which the memcached protocols will recognize a
timeout as a delta. Greater than 30 days and it interprets it as an
absolute time in seconds since the epoch.

This helps to address an often difficult-to-debug problem of time
drift between memcache clients and the memcache servers. Prior to this
change, if a client's time drifts behind the servers, short timeouts
run the danger of not being cached at all. If a client's time drifts
ahead of the servers, short timeouts run the danger of persisting too
long. Using delta's avoids this affect. For absolute timeouts 30 days
or more in the future small time drifts between clients and servers
are inconsequential.

See also bug 1076148 (https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1076148).

This also fixes incr and decr to handle timeout values in the same way
timeouts are handled for set operations.

Change-Id: Ie36dbcedfe9b4db9f77ed4ea9b70ff86c5773310
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:44:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can I get a bit more explanation as to what this is fixing? Or what the enchancement(s) are? Or whatever?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:56:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The current catch_errors (ie without this patch) relinquishes control before the underlying middleware/app has been evaluated. This results in not catching errors in the stack when they occur in either the start_response or in generating the first chunk sent to the client of the underlying stack.

These errors can be seen by GET'ing a manifest that has more segments than the container listing limit. Although https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15928/ fixes the particular problem of many-segment-manifests, it still points to classes of errors that catch_errors is not catching.

This patch does not handle the case where subsequent chunks raise an exception after data has already been sent to the client."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:00:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:22:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
change catch_errors to use WSGIContext

The current catch_errors (ie without this patch) relinquishes control
before the underlying middleware/app has been evaluated. This results
in not catching errors in the stack when they occur in either the
start_response or in generating the first chunk sent to the client of
the underlying stack.

Change-Id: Iecd21e4fc7e30fa20239d011f69216354b50baf1

commit_message:
Remove volumes and gigabytes quota support

Now that nova doesn't do volumes nativly these quotas need to be set in cinder.

fix bug 1078089
part of blueprint delete-nova-volume

Change-Id: I9ee3865020be0a0c6462b7f71374f04499a3ebe7

[{'created': '2012-11-16 19:35:14.000000000', 'message': 'ReST API: Add a convenience redirect for resources

Since the path stacks/{stack_name}/{stack_id}/resources exists for each
valid stack we can safely redirect to it from stacks/{stack_name}/resources
without having to perform any further checks in the engine, so we may as
well allow it.

Change-Id: I0169493479f8c6840de3edad271cf98e8fd5d1da
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
ReST API: Add a convenience redirect for resources

Since the path stacks/{stack_name}/{stack_id}/resources exists for each
valid stack we can safely redirect to it from stacks/{stack_name}/resources
without having to perform any further checks in the engine, so we may as
well allow it.

Change-Id: I0169493479f8c6840de3edad271cf98e8fd5d1da
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 19:33:04.000000000', 'message': 'RPC API: Include less detail in resource list

Since the stack_list_resources command could be returning data for a large
number of resources, avoid returning the metadata and description (which
are not needed) to save space.

Change-Id: I4e3a46315952f8dd451410622de0d68423abbbf2
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
RPC API: Include less detail in resource list

Since the stack_list_resources command could be returning data for a large
number of resources, avoid returning the metadata and description (which
are not needed) to save space.

Change-Id: I4e3a46315952f8dd451410622de0d68423abbbf2
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Switch to using eventlet_backdoor from oslo.

Instead of using the copy of eventlet_backdoor in nova.common
this switches over to the synced version from oslo.

Change-Id: Ice2e38b9da66b34e19f04af0a99bcdc2cb5b5cd3
Signed-off-by: Matthew Treinish <treinish@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Add some sqlalchemy tweakables

Adds new config options:

sql_pool_size
sql_max_overflow

These are options to tweak the QueuePool that sqlalchemy uses by
default to allow for a larger pool size, etc.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Iae086269182118e12777fa7bbd792a47c847ae99

commit_message:
Ensure cat process is terminated

per bug report we should be terminating that "cat" subprocess at the
end of test_KillFilter.

switching from kill to terminate/wait, add try/finally to make sure we
are ok even if an exception is thrown in between

fixes bug #1079629

Change-Id: I8ca767402a2bd992d4b9579615375eda0c75cb6b

commit_message:
be specific about metadata too long error

Tempest was catching a generic fail on the metadata too
long call, but a very specific error is supposed to be returned,
a 413. In real runs there was a bug in nova which crashed on the
request (fixed in https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1079387).

Fix tempest to only accept a 413 as valid on this request.

Make this an assertRaise test instead of a negative test

Change-Id: Id09394abc863ecd773f56dbc8a965d87ae7dde97

RPC cleanup should occur before killing service threadgroup.
Otherwise, the connection pool is going to be (attempted) emptied
after the thread has been killed.

Signed-off-by: Jeff Peeler <jpeeler@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Change RPC cleanup ordering

RPC cleanup should occur before killing service threadgroup.
Otherwise, the connection pool is going to be (attempted) emptied
after the thread has been killed.

Change-Id: Ie2b2aca495928b7ba39b2175202a072b3592ad72
Signed-off-by: Jeff Peeler <jpeeler@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-11-16 06:11:55.000000000', 'message': 'Make the controller addresses configurable.

The addresses in sample_data were hard-coded to localhost. This is
a problem when deploying not-so-all-in-one deployment -- one controller
and couple of compute nodes. It was also complicating access from
outside.

Change-Id: Iee53c3f4376c3628e1543afb6dc7e964a3a14ab2
'}]
commit_message:
Make the controller addresses configurable.

The addresses in sample_data were hard-coded to localhost. This is
a problem when deploying not-so-all-in-one deployment -- one controller
and couple of compute nodes. It was also complicating access from
outside.

Change-Id: Iee53c3f4376c3628e1543afb6dc7e964a3a14ab2

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 13:11:34.000000000', 'message': 'Ensures User is member of tenant in ec2 validation

It is possible that a user is no longer a member of a tenant when
they attempt to use an ec2 token. This checks to make sure that
the user still has at least one valid role in the tenant before
authenticating them. This should automatically work for the s3
version as well since it is a subclass.

Fixes bug 1064914

Change-Id: Ieb237bae936a7b00ce7ba4d4c59aec6c7a69ec21
'}]
commit_message:
Ensures User is member of tenant in ec2 validation

It is possible that a user is no longer a member of a tenant when
they attempt to use an ec2 token. This checks to make sure that
the user still has at least one valid role in the tenant before
authenticating them. This should automatically work for the s3
version as well since it is a subclass.

Fixes bug 1064914

Change-Id: Ieb237bae936a7b00ce7ba4d4c59aec6c7a69ec21

'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-11-16 02:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you provide some context?  Why is this needed?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-11-16 13:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

From the bug:

Given the following args, the client asks for an endpoint instead of additional credentials (which is preferred):

    $ keystone --token=asdf --os-username=asdf token-get
    Expecting an endpoint provided via either --os-endpoint or env[OS_SERVICE_ENDPOINT]

As a result, users end up bypassing authentication and are more likely to run into issues not having a service catalog, etc.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-16 17:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Edits to the API quick start to:

- update Google Analytics code
- link to the CLI guide rather than embed
- offer a way to retrieve tenantId
- demonstrate with curl a command with X-Auth-Token

commit_message:
Add support for resizes to resource tracker.

Keep track of additional resources required to resize an instance
to a new host.  Also hold resources for a revert resize to the original
host.

This fixes race conditions where the destination host could become
overscheduled.  (or the source host in the event of a revert)

bug 1065267

Change-Id: Ic565d4e2ab9bee40f25fe9f198e1217cdd92ca1b

The problem is, the data I want is not *in* the wsgi context.  Are you stating a preference that I modify this patch to stuff the token validation response into the WSGI environment instead of HTTP headers?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-15 21:22:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I have uploaded a different patch which simply stuffs the verification response into the 'keystone.token_info' variable of the WSGI environment.  See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16230/"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-16 16:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Embed extension data in the headers

The token verification response can have all sorts of extension
data that the auth_token.py middleware doesn't include in any
headers.  This adds optional headers which will contain any
extension data that was present in the verification response.

Change-Id: Icf5b540958c933f9e7961d9d7a867fb62b1d141d

commit_message:
Convenience cmds for l3

Bug #1049551

Add two CLI and unit tests:
quantum net-external-list
(runs net-list with router:external=True filter)
quantum router-port-list <router-id/name>
(runs port-list, filtering with device_id equal to specified router)

Change-Id: I9a9668836ac24d4cbc6a3867ec031611b64ded14

subject: Remove db read from run_instance.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-15 23:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I actually don't feel very good about this patch.  The place where the
db reads are being done now seems unnatural, and having to do it in each
scheduler driver isn't great.  That part is easily addressed by moving
it up into the scheduler manager, but doing it in the scheduler at all
seems weird.

Another option is to have the bdms passed to the scheduler.  
Unfortunately, the compute manager calls this method in the scheduler
service, in addition to the compute part of the API service.  Sending it
to the scheduler would mean that nova-compute has to query for the
mappings from nova-conductor and then send them to the scheduler, so I'm
not sure that's any better than what's here now."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-16 00:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

'}, {'created': '2012-11-16 04:02:00.000000000', 'message': 'Remove db read from run_instance.

This patch removes a db lookup done in run_instance in the compute
manager.  Specifically, it was doing a lookup for the block device
mappings associated with the instance.

The change is quite simple.  It turns out that if a block device mapping
was specified when requesting that the instance be created, then it will
be in request_spec, so just grab it from there.

The compute manager will also reschedule an instance to be created if it
fails for some reason, but this should still work fine, as it passes the

commit_message:
Remove db read from run_instance.

This patch removes a db lookup done in run_instance in the compute
manager.  Specifically, it was doing a lookup for the block device
mappings associated with the instance.

The change is quite simple.  It turns out that if a block device mapping
was specified when requesting that the instance be created, then it will
be in request_spec, so just grab it from there.

The compute manager will also reschedule an instance to be created if it
fails for some reason, but this should still work fine, as it passes the
same request_spec back to the scheduler.

Change-Id: I676756e2a35d5adf1fe2b5369c0df93d0cbd5ee9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 19:29:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove use of nonexistent postgresql-setup.

On Ubuntu the default postgresql data directory is not
/var/lib/pgsql/data so the check to see if that directory
exists is not needed. On Fedora we can assume that the rpm will
create it and initialize it properly. So this line can safely
removed without any issues.

Change-Id: If949f0580eb139f3803b698ee88fceebf958448e
'}]
commit_message:
Remove use of nonexistent postgresql-setup.

On Ubuntu the default postgresql data directory is not
/var/lib/pgsql/data so the check to see if that directory
exists is not needed. On Fedora we can assume that the rpm will
create it and initialize it properly. So this line can safely
removed without any issues.

Change-Id: If949f0580eb139f3803b698ee88fceebf958448e

commit_message:
Don't reference argparse._StoreAction

This is a private implementation detail of argparse, so we don't want
to rely on it. Just sub-class Action instead.

Change-Id: Icfcc782cc334d1bc1d4940bec23af48ead692a9d

commit_message:
Abstract out functionality into plugins

Abstract handlers into plugins and make handlers more generic
Same with Storage and Backends as well

Also now you just subclass the BaseAddressHandler and run self._create
and self._delete in process_noticiation for Notification handling.

This change will allow us to configure options on a pr handler base using the
__plugin_type__ + __plugin_name__ of each plugin to add sections in the configs
easily like:
[handler:nova_fixed]
domain = test.com

[storage:sql]
connection_debug = 100

[backend:bind9]
someopt = x

Also change the default record format of handlers to use octet data

bug #1078935

Change-Id: Ic2ddf5a113dd1a306fce0513da2bfdbda991f647

commit_message:
Volume RPC API Versioning

Add versioning to Volume Rpc API version.  This is initial version
1.0, which is compatible with previous non-versioned RPC API.

Note: this patch slightly change the db.volume_update() behavior,
which now returns updated volume info.

Change-Id: I78036b6ed97c5bc369d8c85307ecaaad8e31ff90

subject: API extension for fpinging instances
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1267, 'name': 'Alexei Ababilov', 'display_name': 'Alexei Ababilov', 'email': 'ilovegnulinux@gmail.com', 'username': 'aababilov'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-29 16:33:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-merge/7853 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-docs/3657 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/8969 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-python26/5123 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-python27/5179 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/9627 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/12133/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/254 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-08-29 17:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have several problems with this patch:

1. First and foremost, nova is in feature freeze; this cannot merge until trunk is opened for Grizzly.

2. You don't define any XML templates.  Extensions like this need to have XML support; there are several extensions you can use as examples, or feel free to ask me questions about how the templates system works.

3. This needs to be severely rate-limited; I think you'll agree that we don't want people to use up all of nova-api's CPU time fping'ing all their servers.  At a minimum, the default rate-limiting configuration needs to have a rule added that limits how frequently this extension can be hit to something reasonable, say, once per minute…though I'd even suggest going for as low as once per hour…

4. You should give some thought to what happens if the fping binary is not available on nova-api's system, and make sure it does something reasonable."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2012-08-30 09:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, I would run pep8 tests on my machine if I had not received this:
$ ./run_tests.sh -p -N
Running PEP8 and HACKING compliance check...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tools/hacking.py", line 479, in <module>
    pep8._main()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1917, in _main
    report = pep8style.check_files()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1588, in check_files
    runner(path)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1597, in input_file
    return fchecker.check_all(expected=expected, line_offset=line_offset)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1340, in check_all
    self.check_logical()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1280, in check_logical
    for result in self.run_check(check, argument_names):
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-08-30 14:06:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

run_tests.py is becoming increasingly deprecated-in-fact, now that jenkins has moved to using tox.  I suggest installing tox to run the unit tests; to invoke, simply call "tox" from the top-level directory.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2012-08-30 18:38:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you, Kevin!

> 1. First and foremost, nova is in feature freeze; this cannot merge until trunk is opened for Grizzly.
No problem, it can wait, of course.

> 2. You don't define any XML templates.
I would like to implement them as well, however, XML API could become deprecated in Grizzly if Vish's proposal will be accepted (https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg15680.html). Frankly speaking, I would be pleasured if we implement a simple XML->json and json->XML translator and put it as a kinda middleware before native JSON API. 

> 3. This needs to be severely rate-limited
I completely agree and a tunable time limit will be implemented.

[{'created': '2012-08-29 16:18:16.000000000', 'message': 'API extension for fpinging instances

It may be interesting for a cloud user or administrator to perform a
simple instance monitoring. A ping could be an acceptable solution: it
is fast and it quite reliable.

API calls.

GET /os-fping?[all_tenants=1]&[include=uuid[,uuid...][&exclude=...]

Performs fping for all VM in the current project and returns results. If
`all_tenants` is requested, returns data for all projects.
`include` and `exclude` are parameters specifying VM masks. Consider
that VM list is `VM_all`, then if `include` is set, the result will be
`VM_all * VM_include`. if `include` is set, the result will be `VM_all -
VM_exclude`. `exclude` is ignored if `include` is specified.

GET /os-fping/<vm-uuid>
Performs a check for single instance.

Implement blueprint fping-instances-ext

commit_message:
API extension for fpinging instances

It may be interesting for a cloud user or administrator to perform a
simple instance monitoring. A ping could be an acceptable solution: it
is fast and quite reliable. A limit for ping is 1 time a minute by
default.

API calls.

GET /os-fping?[all_tenants=1]&[include=uuid[,uuid...][&exclude=...]
Performs fping for all VM in the current project and returns results. If
`all_tenants` is requested, data for all projects is returned.
By default, `all_tenants` is allowed only for admins.
`include` and `exclude` are parameters specifying VM masks. Consider
that VM list is `VM_all`, then if `include` is set, the result will be
`VM_all * VM_include`. if `include` is set, the result will be `VM_all -
VM_exclude`. `exclude` is ignored if `include` is specified.

GET /os-fping/<vm-uuid>
Performs a check for single instance.

Configuration flags.

fping_path - full path to fping

Implement blueprint fping-instances-ext

Change-Id: I7d942270aa52bd6216eda0d7ae366ef0195d52a8

commit_message:
The wrong note in swift/common/ring/utils.py
In swift/common/ring/utils.py
In build_tier_tree():

In Example

The tier tree would look like:

(2,): [(1, 192.168.2.1:6000),
       (1, 192.168.2.2:6000)],

i think it should be

(2,): [(2, 192.168.2.1:6000),
       (2, 192.168.2.2:6000)],

Change-Id: I7032b892f5282014bf0ede8831668ee19f744300

commit_message:
plugin/ryu, linux/interface: remove ryu specific interface driver

Implements blueprint ryu-remove-ryu-specific-interface-driver
Since Ryu specific interface driver is not needed any more,
delete it.

Change-Id: Ic3336e8aac3076ddc949044d7ff25608bb7d297f
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 19:55:08.000000000', 'message': 'Issue a hard shutdown if clean fails on resize up

In the xenapi driver, a clean shutdown is attempted during a resize up.
If the Xenapi raises an exception it is logged and ignored and the
resize will fail later in the process.  This adds a hard shutdown
attempt if the clean shutdown fails.

The resize up case was overlooked in
I458931a19dd2375ad7142d60cb8b6ed274de9483 so this adds it for
consistency and error handling.

Change-Id: Idf4a20433b9d5726db4e54d5cf61a93db57d4cc9
'}]
commit_message:
Issue a hard shutdown if clean fails on resize up

In the xenapi driver, a clean shutdown is attempted during a resize up.
If the Xenapi raises an exception it is logged and ignored and the
resize will fail later in the process.  This adds a hard shutdown
attempt if the clean shutdown fails.

The resize up case was overlooked in
I458931a19dd2375ad7142d60cb8b6ed274de9483 so this adds it for
consistency and error handling.

Change-Id: Idf4a20433b9d5726db4e54d5cf61a93db57d4cc9

commit_message:
Add support for backdoor_port to be returned with a rpc call.

This adds an rpc call for compute and network that will return
the eventlet_backdoor port for the service.

Change-Id: I95fdb5ca9bce9f3128300e3b5601fb2b2fc5e82f
Signed-off-by: Matthew Treinish <treinish@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Make tox.ini run pep8/hacking checks on bin.

This updates the pep8 checks in our tox.ini file so that
we are also scanning the bin directory.

Additionally, it updates the main pep8 check so that it scans
cinder properly as well. Previously there were a bunch of files
getting skipped due to some of the pep8 pattern matching.

Change-Id: Ib47a590303409e62546a75625ee356c9fa7af6ad

commit_message:
Move all mount classes into a subdirectory

The disk API will be growing some new classes in future commits.
To avoid ambiguity in module names, move all the mount classes
into a subdirectory nova/virt/disk/mount/

blueprint: virt-disk-api-refactoring
Change-Id: I03898b4060bd0c488713c9d9f19caebdcd39113c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-16 00:04:31.000000000', 'message': "don't explode if a 413 didn't set Retry-After

We use 413 error code not only for temporary out of memory
conditions but also for over quota issues. These kinds of
requests don't set a Retry-After header, but the code assumed
that was a valid key, thus exploding on a KeyError. Issue
caught in looking at tempest traces.

Fixes bug #1079387

Change-Id: Id406ab0799a35220b189b2e5292be092eb821ec5
"}]
commit_message:
don't explode if a 413 didn't set Retry-After

We use 413 error code not only for temporary out of memory
conditions but also for over quota issues. These kinds of
requests don't set a Retry-After header, but the code assumed
that was a valid key, thus exploding on a KeyError. Issue
caught in looking at tempest traces.

Fixes bug #1079387

Change-Id: Id406ab0799a35220b189b2e5292be092eb821ec5

[{'created': '2012-11-15 20:29:26.000000000', 'message': 'Fix use_single_default_gateway

With FlatDHCP and use_single_default_gateway nova-network creates
an invalid entry in the dnsmasq .opts file for the network that
contains a blank router option.  New instances will not receive
a default gateway.

Change-Id: I4c2da61def0681b7b253ae387bf83c069484e28b
Fixes: bug #1075859
'}, {'created': '2012-11-15 22:40:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix use_single_default_gateway

With FlatDHCP and use_single_default_gateway nova-network creates
an invalid entry in the dnsmasq .opts file for the network that
contains a blank router option.  New instances will not receive
a default gateway.

Change-Id: I4c2da61def0681b7b253ae387bf83c069484e28b
Fixes: bug #1075859
'}]
commit_message:
Fix use_single_default_gateway

With FlatDHCP and use_single_default_gateway nova-network creates
an invalid entry in the dnsmasq .opts file for the network that
contains a blank router option.  New instances will not receive
a default gateway.

Change-Id: I4c2da61def0681b7b253ae387bf83c069484e28b
Fixes: bug #1075859

commit_message:
Add support for positional arguments

argparse makes it awkward to implement the current cfg API where we
simply return the leftover arguments to the caller.

Very few cfg users actually rely on this functionality and for those
cases it probably makes more sense for them to explicitly register
positional arguments or sub-parsers.

Add support for positional arguments via a 'required' Opt attribute:

  opt = StrOpt('foo', positional=True)
  conf.register_cli_opt(opt)
  conf(['bar'])
  conf.foo == 'bar'

Change-Id: Iea746d710237e1ea26c1ef4871643941d1df09bd

commit_message:
Use stock argparse behaviour for optional args

optparse would print "Options" but argparse prints "optional arguments".

The default argparse behaviour is fine, let's stick with that.

Change-Id: Ib53a2581af9d776e9a7c1cd90eebe89b70034e57

commit_message:
Use stock argparse --usage behaviour

optparse would substitute the program name for %prog, but argparse
requires %(prog)s. Also, optparse would print 'Usage:' whereas
argparse prints 'usage:'.

Neither optparse behaviour that's worth retaining, let's just use
the default argparse behaviour.

Change-Id: Ied2acb37c366f1a45aed72b6b76f11e2de23828e

commit_message:
Use stock argparse --version behaviour

optparse prints the version to stdout, argparse prints the version to
stderr.

There's no need to preserve the old optparse behaviour, let's just stick
with argparse behaviour.

Change-Id: Ie141c72112a63149d098afa9db55a95a309e79d7

commit_message:
Remove add_option() method

argparse just has an add_argument() method, so there's no reason for us
to keep add_option() around.

Change-Id: I6f4be089ceaf0fd8c4c99565af392b445916172e

* Set DATABASE_TYPE in stackrc
* Allow setting DATABASE_TYPE in localrc to work
  (use_database() essentially just sets DATABASE_TYPE at this stage
  so continuing to use it is equivalent)
* Validate DATABASE_TYPE in stack.sh.

Change-Id: Ibb080c76e6cd7c6eebbb641a894d54b1dde78ca6

commit_message:
Simplify database selection

Do not require every script that sources stackrc to also
source lib/databases.

* Move use_databases() to functions
* Set DATABASE_TYPE in stackrc
* Allow setting DATABASE_TYPE in localrc to work
  (use_database() essentially just sets DATABASE_TYPE at this stage
  so continuing to use it is equivalent)
* Validate DATABASE_TYPE in stack.sh.
* Change sudo to postgresql user to go through root to eliminate
  password prompt
* fix use_database error condition

Change-Id: Ibb080c76e6cd7c6eebbb641a894d54b1dde78ca6

commit_message:
Fix use of 'volume' variable name

Using 'volume' as a variable name conflicts with the module imported by
the same name.  This removes pyflakes warnings.

Change-Id: I938e6f07790973d0dd72ab0f22aa8fde597f9dd7

commit_message:
Fix a couple uses of FLAGS

The services API extension was still using FLAGS.  And baremetal virt
driver define FLAGS but never used it.

Change-Id: I95c78d04f9103f13c09cbdbc23d6d4ed0d39dde8

commit_message:
Remove nova.flags imports from scheduler code

nova.flags is no longer needed.  nova.config is now used.

Removes FLAGS and LOG from baremetal_host_manager completely, which
doesn't use them.

commit_message:
Remove nova.flags imports from bin/*

nova.flags is no longer needed except to load nova config options shared
across multiple daemons.

This removes nova.flags from the bin programs and makes sure that
nova.flags is imported in nova.config for now.

Change-Id: If066ac0070387bee4b41e6a78ad972f7a0955c75

commit_message:
Refactor db_replicator's roundrobin_datadirs

roundrobin_datadirs was returning any .db file at any depth in the
accounts/containers structure. Since xfs corruption can cause such
files to appear in odd places at times (only happened on one drive of
ours so far, but still...), I've refactored this function to only
return .db files at the proper depth.

Change-Id: Id06ef6584941f8a572e286f69dfa3d96fe451355

commit_message:
Adds documentation for Hyper-V testing

The Hyper-V Nova Compute plugin uses Windows Management Instrumentation
(WMI) as the main API for hypervisor related operations.
WMI has a database / procedural oriented nature that can become difficult to
test with a traditional static mock / stub based unit testing approach.

This document explains the architecture of the implemented infrastructure.

Change-Id: I24e2893da487571ac82f44d1dc213c9cdb7166d0

url, which incorerctly replaces "/" with "\" on Windows.

Adds also some refactoring in nova.virt.hyperv.vmops and in the hyperv tests.

commit_message:
Adds support for ConfigDriveV2 in Hyper-V

Supports iso9660 ConfigDriveV2 drives, which can be attached to the
instance on boot as VHD or ISO.
Admin password injection can be selectively enabled for security concerns.

Updates also the hyperv tests.

Change-Id: I22d1ab57bd2f75ddf8758b2ea1a958d7bbe35731

commit_message:
Do not update flavor if timeout occurs in resize.

This update also makes sure the guest does not change my.cnf values
unnecessarily.

Change-Id: Ibb93e6fd2835f41f273c171c1b854facacc9e4a0

commit_message:
Throw validation response into the environment

Allow other middleware access to the raw response from the token
validation step by adding it to the WSGI environment in the
'keystone.token_info' variable.

Change-Id: I3849598d6eefd2bfcb04e27d723f08fb1935c231

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-15 23:35:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Since we're moving flags around, would this be a good time to move the common options into a function?

It can be confusing when a module is imported but seemingly unused when it's just there for the side effects of adding the common options."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-15 23:38:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I was going to take a different approach to this - basically move most of the options in nova.flags to be better scoped and then later only move the options into nova.config that are truly global

See the "scope" section in https://etherpad.openstack.org/grizzly-nova-config-options

This way is fine too, though

One thing I'd like to avoid is projects importing nova.config in order to have a given config option be declared - you should instead do

  CONF.import_opt('foo', 'nova.config')

I'm going to work on eliminating the current cases of implicit 'have option be registered by importing nova.flags''}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-15 23:39:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

commit_message:
Move nova shared config options to nova.config

This strips nova.flags down to be left just for backwards compatibility
with add-ons importing nova.flags and using nova.flags.FLAGS

Change-Id: Ie3fcae25e05ea9ba97f51bc90b91817ed776ad80

commit_message:
Allow controller extensions to extend update/show

This change allows controller extensions to define update and show
functions for a resource when the original controller does not
already do so.

Change-Id: If0030e14ebc9c15e43aa64dc7065462376a156c2

commit_message:
Do not alias stdlib uuid module as uuidutils, since nova has uuidutils.

A few tests use "uuid" as a local variable name, and so must alias the
Python stdlib uuid module to something else.  Unfortunately they chose
"uuidutils", but nova has a module called "uuidutils" so this is confusing.
So change "uuidutils" to "stdlib_uuid" to reduce confusion.

Change-Id: I0b8bad19e37220ef7b2fef1291a3308e481647fe
